Source.Common.Name: Mount Manengouba
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Large blocks of obsidian can be found on the southern slopes of Mount Manengouba, near the town of N'Kongsamba, Cameroon (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Ethnominerology: "Tool manufacturing from this source has likely been identified at the nearby archaeological site of Shum Lake, although they have not been geochemically confirmed (Cornelissen 2003)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Cornelissen, Els. 2003. African Archaeological Review 20(1):1-24. ; Global Volcanism Program, 2013. 2013. Volcanoes of the World v. 4.6.2, http://dx.doi.org/10.5479/si.GVP.VOTW4-2013, Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC. ; Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Tibesti
Formation.Type: Hybrid Scoria Kones and Shield Volcano
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Tibesti Volcanic complex has produced obsidian that can be found in a wide area, usually in pumice layers dating to around 2.2-3 mya. Notable deposits can be found in the far west of the complex on a series of cliffs, several volcanos in the center of the complex, and from the volcano of Emi Koussi in the southeast (Gourgaud and Vincent 2004)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Cann, J. R., and Colin Renfrew. 1964. Petrology of Two Continental Alkaline Intraplate Series at Emi Koussi Volcano, Tibesti, Chad. Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research 129:261-290. ; Global Volcanism Program, 2013. 2013. Volcanoes of the World v. 4.6.2, http://dx.doi.org/10.5479/si.GVP.VOTW4-2013, Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC."

Source.Common.Name: Arafali
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Arafali obsidian is found in the northermost tip of the Afar Triangle, in Eritrea. Arafali obsidian has been found in archaeological contexts in the Dahlak Islands, Eritirea; the Farasan Islands, Saudi Arabia;  and on the east side of Yemen in Hureidha, in the Government of Hadramawt (Khalidi 2010)."
Other.Names: "An alternate name for this source is Hawakil Source 19 (Khalidi 2010)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Cann, J. R., and Colin Renfrew. 1964. Rose (editors). Springer, Dordrecht. 279-291."

Source.Common.Name: Afar
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "This source represents and unidentified obsidian deposit in the Afar Triangle, denoted as Afar 1 per Khalidi et al. 2010."
Bibliographies: "Khalidi, Lamya, Clive Oppenheimer, Bernard Gratuze, Sophie Boucetta, Ali Sanabani, and Ahmed Al-Mosabi. 2010. Cenozoic Magmatism Throughout East Africa Resulting from the Impact of a Single Plume. Nature 395:788-791."

Source.Common.Name: Dabbahu
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian on from the Dabbahu Volcano is found in flows from the summit downhill in a northwest direction, as well as at a vent to the northeast - which is called Da'Ure and represents a geochemically unique source. Obsidian from this area is lacking phenocrysts, and represent the youngest eruptive activity from the complex (Field et al. 2012)."

Source.Common.Name: Worja
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian deposits for the Worja source are found on the easternmost edge of the Gademotta Ridge, which exists as the northern remenants of the caldera. Worja obsidian is of high quality, and has been heavily exploited historically (Shackley and Sahale 2017)."

Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Akira obsidian is of poor quality and not common in archaeological contexts (Merrick and Brown 1984)."

Source.Common.Name: Cedar Hill
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Eburru Volcano is a southern member of the Quaternary volcanics in the Kenya Rift Valley. Obsidian flows are geologically young and form near the fissures anf faults (Kiende and Kandie 2015)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Eburu, Eburru Station (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Elementeita
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Elementeita obsidian source is found as noduldes and part of young domes in the badlands between the Eburru Volcano and Lake Elementeita (Kiende and Kandie 2015). Opuru and Elementeita were the primary sources of obsidian exploited by pastoralists in ther Kenyan Highlands, as early as the Neolithic (Goldstein and Munyiri 2017)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Lake Elementeita, Elmenteita, Elmenteita Badlands, and Elementaita (Smithsonian Global Volcanism Program and Kiende and Kandie 2015)."

Source.Common.Name: Emuruangogolak
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian from Emuruangogolak volcano originate from a thick band starting at the top of the wall on Caldera II, on the west side within the pyroclastic flow deposits. Obsidian here is a green brown color and contains a large amount of phenocrysts (typically anorthoclase, clinopyroxene, and fayalite) (Weaver 1977)."

Source.Common.Name: Menengai
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Menengai obsidian is a green-grey and may be found as: abundant small nodules throughout the geothermal field, flow deposits in the Menengai Caldera, and as small  fragments in the surrounding pumice matrix (Omondi 2011)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Northeast Menengai (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Ol Donyo Nyegi
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Ol Donyo Nyegi is a large volcano that is part of the Magadi Volcanic Complex, and it is composed mostly of thick alternating bands of obsidian and yellow-grey scoria ash - although there is a large flow of vesicular obsidian at the summit. The obsidian is a red-brown color and contains many phenocrysts, typically orthoclase feldspar (Baker 1958)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Ol Doinyo Nyokie, Ol Doinyo Nyegi, Oldonyo Nyegi, Magadi, and Magadi East (IAOS World Source Catalog and Baker 1958)."

Cenozoic Magmatism Throughout East Africa Resulting from the Impact of a Single Plume. Nature 395:788-791. ; Baker, B. H. 1958. Geology of the Magadi Area. Geological Survey of Kenya, Report No. 42."

Source.Common.Name: Ol Karia
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Ol Karia Volcanic Complex is found in the center of the Kenyan RIft Valley, south of the Eburru Volcano and north of the Suswa Caldera. Most igenous activity is composed of  fissure eruptions on the graben floor, with the obsidian flow in the center  of the area being the youngest (Omenda 1998)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Olkaria, Ol Karia Hill, and OIkaria Hill (Omenda 1998)."

Source.Common.Name: Olongai
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Olongai is a volcanic area within the Menengai Complex in the Kenyan RIft Valley, a few kilometeres nothwest of the Menengai Caldera (Omondi 2011)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an  alternate name for this source includes Ol' Rongai (Omondi 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Opuru
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Opuru and Elementeita were the primary sources of obsidian exploited by pastoralists in the Kenyan Highlands, as early as the Neolithic. Opuru obsidian is found in medium sized (up to 1 foot across) blocks on the upper northeastern slopes of Mt. Eburru, most notably near steam vents (Goldstein and Munyiri 2017)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Ol Doinyo Opuru, Oldonyo Opuru, Mt. Eburu, and Mt. Eburru (Goldstein and Munyiyi 2017)."

Source.Common.Name: Olobutot 1
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Olobutot is a north-south trending fault that runs through the Olkaria Complex (Owens et al. 2015), which is found in the center of the Kenyan RIft Valley, south of the Eburru Volcano and north of the Suswa Caldera (Omenda 1998)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Ololbutot and Oserian Farm (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Mackinder Valley 1
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Mackinder Valley is a produced by two lateral moraines found on the north westwern slope of Mount Kenya. Lava outcrops are found on the valley floor and on the northern ridge, with obsidian subsource 1 being 1/3 of the way to the peak and subsources 2 and 3 being found about 1/2 of the way up (Baker 1967)."

Source.Common.Name: North Island 1
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "North Island obsidian is found on a volcanic complex island, a large caldera composed of cinder cones and numerous craters, in the northern portion of Lake Turkana. There are many obsidian flows found on the island, and are geochemically distinct enough to be seperated out into 4 subsources (Ndiema et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Ndiema Suregei Source 2
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Suregei obsidian is found in many outcrops across its large plateau namesake. the area was heavily exploited historically and flaking debris is common (Ndiema et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Olobutot 2
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior

Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Oserian Farm (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Ololerai CMN
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Olerai (Brown et al. 2013)."

Source.Common.Name: Rigo Cave
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Rigo Cave obsidian is found in a thin band within the Tertiary Pyroclastic lapilli that makes up the layer that the Rigo Cave was carved into (Brown et al. 2013). The Rigo Cave, southwest of Lake Naivasha, produces obsidian fragments that are not large enough to used in tool production, and are thought to have come from weathering of the cave roof as opposed to having have been left by human activity (Wandibba 1983)."

Source.Common.Name: Southern Suguta 1
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian from Emuruangogolak volcano originate from a thick band starting at the top of the wall on Caldera II, on the west side within the pyroclastic flow deposits. Obsidian here is a green brown color and contains a large amount of phenocrysts (typically anorthoclase, clinopyroxene, and fayalite) (Weaver 1977)."

Source.Common.Name: Ndiema Suregei Group General
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Suregei obsidian is found in many outcrops across its large plateau namesake. the area was heavily exploited historically and flaking debris is common (Ndiema et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Lukenya
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Lukenya obsidian 'bombs and lapilli were located on top of, weathering out of, and embedded within a welded tuff that outcrops over several kilometers on the Athi Plains about 5 km east of Lukenya Hill.' The nodules are typically 1-2 cm, and were used in microlith tool making (Kusimba 2001)."

Source.Common.Name: Morento
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "This source is used as a proxy for Madagascan obsidian whose geochemistry is not in the database."
Bibliographies: "Vincent, E. A. 1949. The Chemical Composition and Physical Properties of the Resdiual Glass of the Kap Daussy Tholeiite Dike, East Greenland. Mineralogical Magazine 29:208-246. "

Source.Common.Name: Bory Crater
Geology: "Residual glass from Eskdalemuir tholeiite dike in the Bory Crater, Southern Uplands, Piton de la Fouraise, Runion Island. The glass is described as a mostly transparent light brown containing very few inclusions (Ellie 1956)."
Bibliographies: "Ellie, R. B. 1956. The Eskdalemuir Tholeiite and its Contribution to an Understanding of Tholeiite Genesis. Mineralogical Magazine 31:245-254. "

Source.Common.Name: Gough's Island
Geology: "Obsidian from Gough's Island is brown-green in color and contains many pores, but few phenocrysts (George 1920)."
Bibliographies: "George, William Owsley. 1920. The Relation of the Physical Glasses to Their Chemical Composition, University of Minnesota."

Source.Common.Name: Abasurin
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Cann, J. R., and Colin Renfrew. 1964. Characterization of Obsidian and its Application to the Mediterranean Region. The Prehistory Society 8:111-112."

Source.Common.Name: Mount Takahe
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Mount Takahe features obsidian near it's summit, in the form of pyroclastic bombs and flows (Palais 1985)."
Bibliographies: "Palais, Julie Michelle. 1985. Tephra Layers and Ice Chemistry in Byrd-Station Ice Core, Antarctica, Ohio State University."

Source.Common.Name: Deception Island
Geology: "This source can be found in the lava block on Ross Hill, Deception Island (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Global Volcanism Program, 2013. 2013. Volcanoes of the World v. 4.6.2, http://dx.doi.org/10.5479/si.GVP.VOTW4-2013, Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC. ; Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Zavodovski Island
Geology: "Obsidian from this source was collected off of a pumice raft by the crew of the H.M.S. Protector in 1962, and was attributed to the seamount eruptions from Zavodovski Island (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include South Sandwich Island (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Global Volcanism Program, 2013. 2013. Volcanoes of the World v. 4.6.2, http://dx.doi.org/10.5479/si.GVP.VOTW4-2013, Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC. ; Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Rallier-du-Baty Peninsula
Geology: "Rallier-du-Baty Peninsula of the Kerguelen Archipelago features highly porphyritic obsidian flows that contain feldspar phenocrysts, notably at the Vallee du Tellurometre in an extracaldera sill outside of Dome Carva (Gagnevin et al. 2003)."
Bibliographies: "Gagnevin, D., R. Ethien, B. Bonin, B. Moine, G. Freaud, M. C. Gerbe, J. Y. Cottin, G. Michon, S. Tourpin, G. Mamias, C. Perrache, and A Giret. 2003. Open-System Process in the Genesis of Silica-oversaturated Alkaline Rocks of the Rallier-du-Baty Peninsula, Kerguelen Archipelago (Indian Ocean). Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research 123:267-300."

Source.Common.Name: Bouvet Island
Geology: "Bouvet Island has obsidian described as being black and lacking any discernable phenocrysts (Le Roex and Erkland 1982)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Bouvetya (Le Roex, 1982)."
Bibliographies: "Le Roex, Anton P., and A. J. Erlank. 1982. Quantitative Evaluation of Fractional Crystallization in Bouvet Island Lavas. Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research 13:309-338."

Source.Common.Name: Candlemas Island
Geology: "The southern end of Candlemas Island is composed of relatively older, more erroded basalt and obsidian flows (Pearce et al. 1995)."
Bibliographies: "Pearce, Julian A., Peter E. Baker, Peter E. Harvey, and Ian W. Luff. 1995. Geochemical Evidence for Subduction Fluxes, Mantle Melting and Fractional Crystallization Beneath the South Sandwich Island Arc. Journal of Petrology 36(4):1073-1109."

Source.Common.Name: Akhurian 1
Geology: "The Akhurian River carries nodules from upriver to form a secondary alluvial deposit. Obsidian here is described as black, red, or brown, small in size, and lacking phenocrysts (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Akhurian River and Handere (IAOS World Source Catalog, Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."

Source.Common.Name: Akhurian 2
Geology: "The Akhurian River carries nodules from upriver to form a secondary alluvial deposit. Obsidian here is described as black, red, or brown, small in size, and lacking phenocrysts (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Akhurian River and Hamamli (IAOS World Source Catalog, Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."

Source.Common.Name: Arteni 1
Geology: "The Arteni Complex makes up the southwest portion of the Aragats Massif, where obsidian blocks are typically found in layers of pumice. Glass may have banding, high quality, and ranges from black, grey, brown, translucent (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Arteni A, Mez Arteni, Aragatz, and Talin (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Arteni 2
Geology: "The Arteni Complex makes up the southwest portion of the Aragats Massif, where obsidian blocks are typically found in layers of pumice. Glass may have banding, high quality, and ranges from black, grey, brown, translucent (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."

Source.Common.Name: Arteni 3
Geology: "The Arteni Complex makes up the southwest portion of the Aragats Massif, where obsidian blocks are typically found in layers of pumice. Glass may have banding, high quality, and ranges from black, grey, brown, translucent. There is a subsource of Artnei 3 known as Artnei 3b (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Arteni C, Pokr Arteni, and Talin (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Ashotsk
Geology: "Ashotsk obsidian is found on the southwest foothills of the Djavakheti Range, and have limited surface deposits. The glass occurs in small nodules, lacks phenocrysts, and ranges in color from black, brown, and grey - and may contain red banding (Chantaigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Eni-El Sizavit, Sizevit, Yeni-El Agvorik, Aghvorik, and Agvorik (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Gegham-Alaphars
Geology: "Alaphars obsidian is part of the Gegham volcanic subarea, and is found on its mountain namesake (Odonne et al. 2000)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Alaphars (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Gegham-Gyumush
Geology: "Gyumush obsidian is part of the Gegham volcanic subarea, and is found 2km E-SE of its village namesake (Odonne et al. 2000)."

Source.Common.Name: Gegham-Nurnus
Geology: "Nurnus obsidian is part of the Gegham volcanic subarea, and is found 1km N of its village namesake (Odonne et  al. 2000)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Nurnus (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Geghasar
Geology: "Obsidian from Spitasker and Geghaser are geochemically similarm but they can be differentiated by where they formed and by the phenocrysts. They are both found in the Gegham Highlands on large volcanos, with SPitakser being farther south. Nodules are found from the volcano rims eastward down the alluvial depoosits on the playeau, and out into the Ararat Plain via the Azat River. Although geochemically homogenous, Geghasar is of high quality and found in a wide range of colors, and Spitaksar is a uniform black and contains numerous large phenocrysts (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Oddone, M., G. Bigazzi, Y. Keheyan, and S. Meloni. 2000. Characterization of Armenian Obsidians: Implications for Raw Material Supply for Prehistoric Artifacts. Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry 243(3):673-682."

Source.Common.Name: Gutansar
Geology: "Gutansar obsidian is found between its volcano namesake to the banks of the Hrazdan River, and range in size from small nodules to large boulders. The glass is high quality, lacks phenocrysts, may feature red banding or a red mottled coloration, and varies from black, grey, and brown (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Fontan (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Hankavan
Geology: "Hankavan obsidian deposist are found in the Tzaghkuniaz Mountains, '15km NW of the town of Aparan, in the watershed of the Kasakh and Marmarik rivers' (Oddone et al. 2000)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Ankavan (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Sevkar Complex
Geology: "Sevkar obsidian is found along a very thick and long flow near the foothills of its volcanic namesake. This glass is high quality, commonly features red mottling, and ranges from translucent, grey, and black (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Metz Sevkar, Pokr Sevkar, and Greater Sevkar (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Tsaghkunyats Group General
Geology: "Tsaghkunyats obsidian is found in its range namesake, to the northeast of the Aragats complex - and is composed of two geochemically unique subgroups (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Tsaghkuniats, Tsaghkunjats, Ttvakar Volcano, Tzaghkuniaz Mountians, Hankavan, Tsakhkunjats, and Akasar (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Arteni 3b
Geology: "The Arteni Complex makes up the southwest portion of the Aragats Massif, where obsidian blocks are typically found in layers of pumice. Glass may have banding, high quality, and ranges from black, grey, brown, translucent (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Pokr Arteni and Talin (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Bazenk 1
Geology: "Bazenk obsidian is part of the Syunik group, in southern Armenia, with flows originationg from Bazenk Peak (Badalyan et al. 2004)."

Source.Common.Name: Hatis 1
Geology: "Hatis obsidian is found on Mount Hatis - where there are two eruptive events. Subsources Hatis I and II are from the original formation of the volcano 700 ka ago. These subsources are black on the southern slope and turn grey-brown in a westward gradient around the volcano. Hatis III, however, is poor material containing relatively large feldspar phenocrysts and originated from a 50 ka dike intrusion (Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Atis and Akunk deposit (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Satanakar 1
Geology: "The Satanakar dome volcano is ringed by obsidian flows that have all erroded into steep cliff faces with an extensive talus. The glass ranges from grey to black, may feature banding, and is of high quality. Satanakar subsource 1 is found on the southern and western flows, and Satanakar 2 is found primarily in the southeastern flows (Cherry et al. 2010)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Metz Satanakar (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Terceira
Geology: "The volcano responsible for producing Terceira obsidian is a strongly peralkaline magmatic center to the north central portion of the island. There exists a complex history of caldera collapse, melting, and reformation - together with a unique island composition and hydrothermally altered minerals makes this source readily distinguishable (Mungall and Martin 1996)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Pico Alto (Mungall and Martin 1996)."
Bibliographies: "Moore, Richard B. 1990. Volcanic Geology and Eruption Frequency, So Miguel, Azores. Bulletin of Volcanology 52(8):602-614. ; Mungall, James E., and Robert F. Martin. 1996. Extreme Differentiation of Peralkaline Rhyolite, Terciera, a Modern Analogue of Stange Lake, Labrador? Canadian Mineralogist 34:769-777."

Source.Common.Name: Tabonal de los Guanches
Geology: "Obsidian from Tabonal de los Guanches is in abundance and of high quality - and thus has been heavily exploited (Gomez et al. 2008)."
Bibliographies: "Gmez, Cristo, M. Hernndez, and Bertila Galvn Santos. 2008. Estudia Geoqumico de dos Centros de Produccin de Obsidianas en la Prehistoria de Tenerife: El Tabonal de los Guanches (Icod de los Vinos) y el Tabonal Negro (Las Caadas). Trabajos de Prehistoria 65(2):151-168."

Source.Common.Name: Tabonal Negro
Geology: "Obsidian from Tabonal Negro is of high quality and the deposits frequently have associated workshops from early inhabitants (Gomez et al. 2008)."
Bibliographies: "Gmez, Cristo, M. Hernndez, and Bertila Galvn Santos. 2008. Estudia Geoqumico de dos Centros de Produccin de Obsidianas en la Prehistoria de Tenerife: El Tabonal de los Guanches (Icod de los Vinos) y el Tabonal Negro (Las Caadas). Trabajos de Prehistoria 65(2):151-168."

Source.Common.Name: Paektusan Volcano 1
Geology: "Glass from the Paektusan Crater ranges from high to poor quality material, is dull black, and is well known to have been transported over great distances across China during the Holocene. It is thought that the high quality subsources have been made generally inaccessible by volcanic activy, resulting in greater exploitation in lesser quality Paektusan subsources (Jia et al. 2013)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include PNK 1, Changbai Shan Mountains, Tianchi Lake, and Baekdusan 1 (Korean) (IAOS World Source Catalog, Jia et al. 2013)."

Source.Common.Name: Northeast Source A
Geology: "Northeast A obsidian is highly variable in opacity and translucency, typically black, and may have tints of green (Perreault et al. 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Chibzhang Co (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Northeast Source B
Geology: "Northeast B obsidian is known from a single sample that is geochemically distinct from Northeast A, although it is visually similar (semi-opaque black with a green tint) (Perreault et al. 2016)."

Source.Common.Name: Northeast Source C
Geology: "Northeast C obsidian is notably 'enriched in nearly all elements - especially transition metals and rare earth elements' (Perreault et al. 2016)."

Source.Common.Name: Southwest Source A
Geology: "Southwest A obsidian ranges from 'translucent to semi-opaque, with occasional banding of black and grey' (Perreault et al. 2016)."

Source.Common.Name: Southwest Source B
Geology: Southwest B obsidian samples 'are black and semiopaque, with a granular groundmass exhibiting numerous phenocrysts of conspicuous flow-aligned biotite' and are typically found as small nodules in alluvial settings (Perreault et al. 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Balung Co (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Antiparos Island
Ethnominerology: "Historically, obsidian from Antiparos was only exploited by local populations. The glass is described as a 'lustrous jet-black' and is typically found in small nodules (Carter and Contreras 2012)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Soros Hill (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Bombarda-Adhamas
Geology: "Bombarda obsidian is located on from 'a lava dome of submarine origin and the Demenegaki dome complex.' Nodules from this source are found along the nearby coastlines (Arias et al. 2006)."

Source.Common.Name: Giali
Geology: "Obsidian from Giali is visually unique in having white spots, but by containing this many phenocrysts the resulting glass is poor quality for tool construction (Milic 2014)."
Ethnominerology: "Tool use from this source appears to be restricted to the immediate area during the Neolithic, although it was used in the Middle Bronze Age as carved/ground vessels (Milic 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Gyali, Yali (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Erdobenye
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Erdobenye nodules range up to 7cm across and has been used prehistorically for tool manufacturing. The glass is black and opaque, with most of the raw material scattered across the hills of the southern Zemplen Mountains (Williams and Nandris 1977)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Liget Major (Williams and Nandris 1977)."

Source.Common.Name: Md
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian from Mad is green, and most if not all of the deposit has been removed due to a modern quarry (Williams and Nandris 1977)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Mad-Kakashegy (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Olaszliska
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Olaszliszka glass is suspected to be composed of a secondary deposit carried by a river, and is a tool quality green glass (Williams and Nandris 1977)."

Source.Common.Name: Telkibanya
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Telkibanya obsidian is found in large blocks of devitrified rhyolite, with few small nodules of workable material. It has been noted that the quality of this source ranges, but most samples contain large crystals (Williams and Nandris 1977)."

Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Carpathian 2 source is found in the Tokaj Mountains, with two geochemically unique subsources known as 2A and 2B (Thrope et al. 1984)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Carpathian Mountains 2 (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Fremri Nmur
Geology: "Fremri Nmur is a pitchstone deposit in Ketilhyrna, Iceland (Jnasson 2007)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Jnasson, Kristjan. 2007. Silicic Volcanism in Iceland: Composition and Distribution within the Active Volcanic Zones. Journal of Geodynamics 43:101-117."

Source.Common.Name: Hrafntinnuhraun
Geology: "Hrafntinnuhraun obsidian originates from a Holocene obsidian flow at the Torfajkull central volcano, in southern Iceland (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Hrafntinnuhryggur
Geology: "Hraftninnuhryggur is a ridge inside the southeast rim of the Krafla central caldera, and obsidian is very abundant (Jnasson 1994)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Hraftnunruggen (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Journal of Geodynamics 43:101-117."

Source.Common.Name: Katla
Geology: "Katla is an obsidian source found in Kriki, Iceland (Jnasson 2007)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Jnasson, Kristjan. 2007. Silicic Volcanism in Iceland: Composition and Distribution within the Active Volcanic Zones. Journal of Geodynamics 43:101-117."

Source.Common.Name: Kerlingarfjll
Geology: "Kerlingarfjll is an obsidian deposit found in gmundur, Iceland (Jnasson 2007)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Jnasson, Kristjan. 2007. Source.Common.Name: Krafla
Geology: "The Krafla Caldera contains obsidian in an outer layer of the second phase, near the caldera rim (Jnasson 1994)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Source.Common.Name: Landmannalaugar
Geology: "Landmannalaugar obsidian is found in extensive, and up to 6m deep, flows in the Eastern Volcanic Zone of Iceland (Guido 2015)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Guido, Michael. 2015. Continental and Island Rhyolites, University of Colorado."

Source.Common.Name: Orfajokull
Geology: "Orfajokull is one of the three central volcanos in the Eastern Volcanic Zone of Iceland, and the largest stratovolcano in Iceland (Jnasson 2007)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Jnasson, Kristjan. 2007. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Prestahnkur
Geology: "Prestahnkur obsidian is 'Subglacial, effusively erupted rhyolite obsidian vitrophyre' (Clay et al. 2015)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Source.Common.Name: Torfajkull
Geology: "Torfajkull obsidian is aphyric, contains microphenocrysts, originates from the subglacial and subaerial eruptions, and is at least partially hydrothermally altered (Clay et al. 2015)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Continental and Island Rhyolites, University of Colorado."

Source.Common.Name: rarhyrna
Geology: "rarhyrna obsidian is found on its volcano namesake, which lies in the Eastern Volcanic Zone of Iceland (Jnasson 2007)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Jnasson, Kristjan. 2007. Silicic Volcanism in Iceland: Composition and Distribution within the Active Volcanic Zones. Journal of Geodynamics 43:101-117."

Source.Common.Name: Askja 1875
Geology: "This obsidian was sampled from a deposit on the 'agglutinate mantle, (of the) vulconian phase of (the) 1875 eruption of (the) Askja Volcano, Iceland (Macdonald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Baejargil Stream
Geology: "The Baejargil Stream deposit comes from the Husafell Volcanic region in Iceland (Macdnald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Berufjordur
Geology: "Berufjordur obsidian was collected as nodules on top of an acid lava flow in Iceland (Macdnald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Domadalshraun
Geology: "Domadalshraun is an obsidian deposit originating from a Holocene lava flow from the Torfajkull central volcano (Macdnald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Gaesafjoll Complex Little Krafle
Geology: "This source is a 'Hypersthene hyalo- andesite (rhyolite), (found on the) south flank of Little Krafla, Gaesafjoll complex' (Maconald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Laugahraun
Geology: "Laugahraun is an obsidian deposit originating from a Holocene lava flow from the Torfajkull central volcano (Macdnald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Ljsufjll
Geology: "Ljsufjll is an obsidian deposit in wetern Iceland (Macdonald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Reydarfell Dome
Geology: "Rhyolitic glass can be found on the Reydarfell Dome on the Husafell central volcano (Macdonald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Ulfarsfellsna
Geology: "Ulfarsfellsna rhyolitic glass is found as clasts in silicic tuff from Late Tertiary to Early Holocne flows of its volcano namesake in western iceland (Macdonald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Vatnajkull
Loc..Notes: Location is questionable - the glacier has changed a lot since 1920
Geology: "Vatnajkull National Park contains Mount Paul, a 150ft high nunatak made of obsidian (Wadell 1920)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Mount Paul and Plsfjall (Wadell 1920)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523. ; Wadell, Hakon. 1920. Vatnajkull: Some Studies and Observations from the Greatest Glacial Area in Iceland. Geografiska Annaler 2:300-323."

Source.Common.Name: Chanda Limestone
Geology: "Chanda Limestone obsidian originated from Proterozoic eruptions in a deep oceanic rift. The obsidian range from 1-6cm in diameter, clear green glass with few inclusions, and typically occurs in limestone-shale (Bandopadhyay 2004)."
Bibliographies: "Bandopadhyay, P. C. 2004. Proterozoic Deep Marine Volcanic Eruptive Product (Obsidian Glass) in Chanda Limestone, Penganga Group, India: Its Implications for Basin Evolution and Metagenesis. Gondwana Research 7(2):613-619."

Source.Common.Name: Siwana Caldera
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Siwana obsidian has not been observed as having been historically exploited. This deposit was formed in the Neoproterozoic during a continental rifting event, and can be found in southwest Rajasthan, India (Bhushan and Chittora 1999)."
Bibliographies: "Bhushan, S. K., and V. K. Chittora. 1999. Late Proterozoic Bimodal Volcanic Assemblage of Siwana Subsistence Structure, Western Rajasthan, India. Journal of Geological Society of India 53:433-452."

Source.Common.Name: Pavagadh Hill
Geology: "Pavagadh obsidian has not been observed as having been historically exploited. This deposit occurs at Mount Pavagadh, in the southeast Saurashtra Complex (Sheth and Melluso 2008)."
Bibliographies: "Sheth, Hetu C., and Leone Melluso. 2008. The Mount Pavagadh Volcanic Suite, Deccan Traps: Geochemical Stratigraphy and Magmatic Evolution. Journal of Asian Earth Sciences 32:5-21."

Source.Common.Name: Osham Hill
Geology: "Osham Hill obsidian has not been observed as having been historically exploited. The deposit can be found on the west-central edge of the Saurasthra Complex (Sheth et al. 2012)."
Bibliographies: "Sheth, Hetu C., Ashiwini Kumar Choudhary, Ciro Cucciniello, Sudeshna Bhattacharyya, Ramesh Laishram, and Trupti Gurav. 2012. Geology, Petrochemistry, and Genesis of Bimodal Lavas of Osham Hill, Saurshtra, Northwestern Deccan Traps. Journal of Asian Earth Sciences 43:176-192."

Source.Common.Name: Barda Hills Complex
Geology: "Barda Hills obsidian has not been observed as having been historically exploited."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Pariadhar (Dave 1971)."
Bibliographies: "Dave, S. S. 1971. The Geology of the Igneous Complex of the Barda Hills, Saurashtra, Gujarat State (India). Bulletin Volcanologique 35(3):619-632."

Source.Common.Name: Lipari Group General
Geology: "Lipari glass is high quality, transparent, and black. Flows and deposits are found throughout the island (Barca et al. 2007)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Barca, Donatella, Ann Maria De Francsco, and Gino Mirocle Crisci. 2007. Source.Common.Name: Sardinia-A
Geology: "The Gulf of Oristano on the Island of Sardinia contains several geochemically unique obsidiain deposits, which are named Sardinia-A, Sardinia-B1, Sardinia-B2, Sardinia-C1, and Sardinia-C2. Secondary sources follow the Rio Mogoro and Rio Manna out into the Mediterranean, but are primarily sourced to Sardinia-C. Like most glasses in the area, Sardinia obsidian is black, vitreous, and good tool quality (Freund et al. 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes SA Type (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Source.Common.Name: Ichinsky Volcano
Geology: "Near the center of the Central Range on the Kamchatcka Peninsula there are several obsidian deposits surrounding the Ichinsky Volcano. These deposits make up the largest obsidian source on the Peninsula. There are several geochemically distinct sources here: Ichinsky, Nosichan, Paypalpan, and the Belogolovaya. Obsidian from Ichinsky is found in large bands, colored black or blue (Dumond and Bland 2006)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Dumond, Don E., and Richard L. Bland (editors). 2006. Geohemical Types, Petrology, and Genesis of Late Cenozoic Volcanic Rocks from the Kurile-Kamchatka Island-Arc System. International Geology Rericu 36:373-405."

Source.Common.Name: Itkavayam
Geology: "Itkavayam obsidian may be brown, black, maroon, or red - and may be glossy, frosted, or partially transparent (Dumond and Bland 2006)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Kamchatka 2 (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Karimsky Volcano
Geology: "Karimsky obsidian is found in a pumice layer, and found in the Eastern Range of the Kamchatka Peninsula (Dumond and Bland 2006)."

Source.Common.Name: Chasha Maar
Geology: "At the Chasha Maar, in the Southern Range of Kamchatka, large fragments of light grey obsdian are found in tephra layers (Dumond an Bland 2006)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Tolmachev Dol and Maar Chasha (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Source.Common.Name: Nachiki Volcano
Geology: "Nachiki obsidian, at the Shapochka Volcano dome, is found with perlite deposits. The black glass contains plagioclase and pyroxene phenocrysts if found near the summit, but secondary sources along the rivers are high quality, abundant, and transparent (Dumond and Bland 2006)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Bannnaya River and Plotnikova River (Dumond and Bland 2006)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Museum of Natural and Cultural History and Dept. of Anthropology, University of Oregon, in partnership with Shared Beringian Heritage Program, National Park Service, Eugene. ; Volynets, Oleg N. 1991. Geohemical Types, Petrology, and Genesis of Late Cenozoic Volcanic Rocks from the Kurile-Kamchatka Island-Arc System. International Geology Rericu 36:373-405."

Source.Common.Name: Payalpan
Geology: "Near the center of the Central Range on the Kamchatcka Peninsula there are several obsidian deposits surrounding the Ichinsky Volcano. These deposits make up the largest obsidian source on the Peninsula. There are several geochemically distinct sources here: Ichinsky, Nosichan, Payalpan, and the Belogolovaya. Payalpan obsidian is deposited on the western slope of its volcano namesake, with a very large secnddary colluvial deposit. The glass is 'dark with semi-transparent brown veins' (Dumond and Bland 2006)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source is Kamchatka 5 and Paypalpan (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Marekanka River Deposit
Geology: "Small obsidian nodules have been found in secondary contexts near the river Marekanka, Okhotsk, Russia (Macdonald 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Jebel al Abyad locality 5
Geology: "Jebel al Abyad is a Saudia Arabian volcanic complex that produced glassy obsidian - most of which have been devirified. There is no evidence of Jebel al Abyad locality 5 being used in tool production (Baker et al. 1973)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Baker, P. E., R. Brosset, I. G. Gass, and C. R. Neary. 1973. Jebel al Abyad: A Recent Alkalic Volcanic Complex in Western Saudi Arabia. Lithos 6:291-314."

Source.Common.Name: Jabal Shama
Geology: "Jabal Shama is a silicic volcano in Saudi Arabia, where an obsidian deposit be found as a rounded dome on the southern nd of the complex. There is no evidence of Jabal Shama being used in tool production (Surour et al. 2016)."
Bibliographies: "Surour, Adel A., Said A. El-Nisr, and Rami A. Bakhsh. 2016. Origin of Hydrous Alkali Feldspar-Silica Intergrowth in Spherulites from Inter-Plate A2-type Rhyolites at the Jabal Shama, Saudia Arabia. Journal of African Earth Sciences 115:92-107."

Source.Common.Name: Hlinik nad Hronom
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior

Source.Common.Name: Mala Torona
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian from East Slovakia is typically grey (but may be brown), translucent, and does not occur in large flows (Williams-Thrope 1995)."

Source.Common.Name: Szolloske
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian from East Slovakia is typically grey (but may be brown), translucent, and does not occur in large flows (Williams-Thrope 1995). Szolloske nodules are medium sized, 6km east of Satorajaujhely, Slovakia (Williams and Nandris 1977)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Vinicky (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Gllda 1
Geology: "The Gllda Massif was formed in the early Pleistocene, producing several geochemically unique obsidian extrusions during its complex evolution. Gllda 1 consists of two veins that range from brown, black, and transparent - and may feature banding. These deposits are found in the basin to the south-west of the massif (Binder et al. 2011)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes West Gllda 1 (Binder et al. 2011)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Tectonic Control of the Development of the Neogene-Quaternary Central Anatolian Volcanic Province, Turkey. Geological Journal 28:357-369."

Source.Common.Name: Gllda 2
Geology: "The Gllda Massif was formed in the early Pleistocene, producing several geochemically unique obsidian extrusions during its complex evolution. Gllda 2 consists of small nodules found in secondary contexts. The glass is typically green-black and features banding. These deposits are found on the north-western tip of the massif (Binder et al. 2011)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes West Gllda 2 (Binder et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Gllda 7
Geology: "The Gllda Massif was formed in the early Pleistocene, producing several geochemically unique obsidian extrusions during its complex evolution. Gllda 7 range from pebbles to medium nodules, and are typically black but may be 'marbled black and red.' These deposits are found on the southern tip of the massif (Binder et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Gllda 4a
Geology: "The Gllda Massif was formed in the early Pleistocene, producing several geochemically unique obsidian extrusions during its complex evolution. Gllda 4 obsidian is grey with slight banding, and may be found as large blocks. These deposits are found on the north-east trending arm (Binder et al. 2011)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes East Gllda 1 (Binder et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Gllda 4b
Geology: "The Gllda Massif was formed in the early Pleistocene, producing several geochemically unique obsidian extrusions during its complex evolution. Source.Common.Name: Gllda 5
Geology: "The Gllda Massif was formed in the early Pleistocene, producing several geochemically unique obsidian extrusions during its complex evolution. Gllda 5 obsidian is dark grey, of high quality, and may feature large bubbles. These deposits are found on eastern slopes above the Kmrc village (Binder et al. 2011)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include East Gllda 2 and Kmrc (Binder et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Gllda 6
Geology: "The Gllda Massif was formed in the early Pleistocene, producing several geochemically unique obsidian extrusions during its complex evolution. Gllda 6 obsidian is found as large slabs and of notably poor quality. These deposits are found on the western slopes of the massif (Binder et al. 2011)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include East Gllda and Bozky (Binder et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Sandy Braes
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "This obsidian is saturated with large phenocrysts and represent very poor tool quality material. Source.Common.Name: Yafa' Ridge 1
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior

Source.Common.Name: El Chayal
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Chayal obsidian is a medium grey and waxy in appearance. The glass also 'Frequently (has) dark to black banding, unusually wide and irregular when present, dusty appearance' (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "'El Chayal was the most important source of obsidian for Lowland Maya centers during the Classic period', and is considered overall one of the largest sources in Mesoamerica (Cobean et al. 1991, Doering 2002)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include La Joya, La Jolla, and Las Navajas Palencia (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Ixtepeque
Geology: "Ixtepeque obsidian was heavily exploited and typically dominates lithic assemblages in this region (Shackley 2004). The glass varies from grey to black with stripes - with a few samples being mottled red (Cobean et al. 1971)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Agua Blanca, Cerro Chaguitillo, Cerro Pino, Redondo, and Papalhuapa (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Laguna de Ayarza
Ethnominerology: "Laguna de Ayarza has 'Not been represented much in artifactual material analyzed so far' (Stross et al. 1983)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Laguna de Ayarza and Lake Ayarza (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Media Cuesta
Ethnominerology: "Media Cuesta obsidian was a very minor source of obsidian historically (Cobean et al. 1991)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes San Rafaelito (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: San Martn Jilotepeque Group General
Geology: "San Martn obsidian is dark grey with possible irregular black banding, but frequently has particulates that can give it an overall red-brown hue. The quality of this glass is highly variable. Inclusions are common from dust to sand grain size and can occur in cloud-like formations (Doering 2002). Deposits are typically difficult to reach and are exposed on the banks of the Pixcay River (Stross et al. 1983)."
Ethnominerology: "Use of this source peaked during the Middle Formative period, when it became the dominant material throughout the Mayan Lowlands and the Chiapas Highlands (Doering 2002)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Aldea, Chatalun, Chimaltenango, Choatalum, Inyaalchay, Las Burras, Pachay, Pixcay, Ro Pixcay, and Sauces Type C (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Puente Chetunal
Geology: "Puente Chetunal obsidian outcrops are found around the bridge of Carretera Interoceanica (CA9) about 20 meters above the Motagua River, and at another deposit 30 to 50 kilometers west.The is a strong possibility that these represent an additional source of El Chayal obsidian (Stross et al. 1983)."

Source.Common.Name: Ginope
Geology: "Obsidian from Ginope is commonly found as water-transported nodules up to 10cm across (Sheets et al. 1990)."
Ethnominerology: "Use of the Ginope source appears to have been restricted to the immediate area (Sheets et al. 1990)."

Source.Common.Name: La Union
Ethnominerology: "La Union obsidian can be found in 'a variety of temporal contexts from Formative through Late and Terminal Classic sites in Honduras' (Shackley 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Copan, Agua Helada, Quebrada Agua Helada, and Torreno Negro (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: La Esperanza
Geology: "The Esperanza source is in southwest Honduras, in the Department of Intibuca (Sheets et al. 1990)."
Ethnominerology: "Source exploitation has occurred locally from 'The Classic period, and likely during the Preclassic and Postclassic periods as well' (Sheets et al. 1990)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Lake Yajoa (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: El Regino
Geology: "El Regino obsidian, named after a nearby rock shelter, is located approximately 10 km south of Puertocitos, Baja California, Mexico. The primary source can be found as small nodules up to 5 cm in diameter in a volcanic tuff (Panich et al. 2012)."

Source.Common.Name: Puerto el Parral
Geology: "The Puerto el Parral obsidian source is 62 km south of San Felipe, Baja California, Mexico. Nodules are common in the perlite lava deposits (Panich et al. 2012)."
Ethnominerology: "The archaeological distribution of Puerto el Parral glass extends to the Pacific Coast in the San Quintn-El Rosario region' (Panich et al. 2012)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source may include Arroyo Matomi and San Felipe (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: San Felipe
Geology: "'The obsidian referred to as San Felipe glass is perhaps the best known of the unknown sources in Baja California. San Felipe obsidian has previously been reported in archaeological contexts as far north as Riverside and San Diego counties and as far west as the Pacific Coast, making it the most widely distributed source in northern Baja California. Yet its exact geological source is unknown, and its geochemical signature is derived from samples collected from secondary geological deposits of only vague provenance.' (Panich et al. 2012)."

Source.Common.Name: Otumba
Geology: "Otumba obsidian is black with grey bands, and sometimes opaque (Doering 2002). The source has been largely removed, due to both exploitation and erosion. It is located on the inner slopes of Cerro Soltepec. Artifacts from it have been found at most sites in central Mexico, the Valley of Oaxaca, and the Maya Lowlands (Glascock et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Soltepec (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Penjamo-1
Geology: "Obsidian from Penjamo can be found in a clear grey flow band streching over 8km, immediatly due west of its town namesake in Guanjuato, Mexico. The best exposures can be found near the La Golondrina dam shoreline, where there is copious amounts of tool working debris. There are also vast quantities of obsidian in the 'flows embedded in volcanic ash in some abandoned modern quarries on Mexico Highway 110 on the southern edge of Churipitzeo' (Cobean 2002)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Sierra de Penjamo (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Sierra de Pachuca-1
Geology: "Pachuca obsidian is transparent green with a green-gold tint. The glass is of fine quality for tool making and contains very few inclusions (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Pachuca was one of the earliest sources exploited in Central Mexico, with blades associated with mammoth kill sites in the Late Pleistocene (Doering 2002)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Cerro del las Navajas, Cerro de Minillas, Cerro Pelon, Cruz del Milagro, El Chapulin, El Ocote, Huasca, Pachuca Rancho, Guajalote, and Sierra de las Navajas (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Tulancingo Group General
Geology: "Tulancingo obsidian is found in several extensive flows, and outcrops are typically exposed on hillsides and rivercuts. The material is typically grey green, but other colors are possible (Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."
Ethnominerology: "The use of this glass peaked during the Postclassic Period, as it was the primary source of obsidian for the 'Triple Allience military expansion through Tulancingo due to its strategic location on a route toward he Gulf of Mexico' (Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Pizarrin, Pizzarin, and Rancho Tenango (IAOS World Source Catalog, Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."

Source.Common.Name: La Lobera
Geology: "La Lobera is high quality obsidian and is found in many colors - including 'rainbow' varieties. The source was heavily exploited during pre-Hispanic times (Glascock et al. 2010)."

Source.Common.Name: Cruz Negra
Geology: "Ucareo glass is a dense and opaque black, has a blue tint, and contains small phenocrysts that are only seen on thin edges. There are two subsources, Ucareo-1 and Ucareo-2, with Ucareo-2 the lesser exploited material (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Obsidian from this source has been documented as far away as Belize, and the deposits have been heavily mined (Doering 2002)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Ucareo-2 (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Ucareo
Geology: "Ucareo glass is a dense and opaque black, has a blue tint, and contains small phenocrysts that are only seen on thin edges. There are two subsources, Ucareo-1 and Ucareo-2, with Ucareo-1 being the more common for tool making (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Obsidian from this source has been documented as far away as Belize, and the deposits have been heavily mined (Doering 2002)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Ucareo-1 (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Volcan Las Navajas
Geology: "Volcan las Navajas obsidian is located 18 km east of Tepic, Nayarit, Mexico. Obsidian can be found in outcrops on the eastern edge of the caldera, and tend to be of high quality, opaque green glass (Glascock et al. 2010)."
Ethnominerology: "Evidence for mining of obsidian from Volcan Las Navajas during pre-Hispanic times is extensive, with large accumulations of waste material from tool production found throughout the area (Glascock et al. 2010)."

Source.Common.Name: Guadalupe Victoria
Ethnominerology: "Obsidian from Guadalupe Victoria is not considered tool-making material (Doering 2002)."

Source.Common.Name: Paredn Group General
Geology: "Paredn obsidian is transparent, black to grey, and may exhibit a slight beige tint. It can have 'Interior globular inclusions (0.5-1.0 mm) appearing as round-to-oblong black spheres with sharply defined edges. Smaller stipple-like particulates are common quartz-like inclusions when at the surface' (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Paredn obsidian has been exploited by Pre-Columbian groups from the Early Formative to the Late Post-Classic periods. The source can be found to the southwest of the Metzitilan Valley, and most cobbles are found in secondary fluvial deposits (Berning 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Tecocomulco (Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."

Source.Common.Name: Zaragoza Oyamales subsource
Geology: "Zaragoza glass is opaque and dense black, may contain particulates, and exhibits lateral banding of dark-grey to black. The flows are several meters thick (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Zaragoza obsidian was heavily exploited and used during the Formative Period, and it is common in lithic assemblages. Mines and workshops can be found in the southern deposits, while the northern ones appear untouched. The deposits near Oyamales represent the southernmost of these deposits (Doering 2002)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Oyameles (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Sierra de Pachuca Group General
Geology: "Pachuca obsidian is transparent green with a green-gold tint. The glass is of fine quality for tool making and contains very few inclusions (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Pachuca was one of the earliest sources exploited in Central Mexico, with blades associated with mammoth kill sites in the Late Pleistocene (Doering 2002)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Cerro del las Navajas, Cerro de Minillas, Cerro Pelon, Cruz del Milagro, El Chapulin, El Ocote, Huasca, Pachuca Rancho, Guajalote, and Sierra de las Navajas (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Pizarrin
Geology: "Tulancingo obsidian is found in several extensive flows, and outcrops are typically exposed on hillsides and rivercuts. The material is typically grey green, but other colors are possible (Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."
Ethnominerology: "The use of this glass peaked during the Postclassic Period, as it was the primary source of obsidian for the 'Triple Allience military expansion through Tulancingo due to its strategic location on a route toward he Gulf of Mexico' (Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Pizarrin and Pizzarin(IAOS World Source Catalog, Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."
Bibliographies: "Carballo, David M., Jennifer Carballo, and Hector Neff. 2007. Formative and Classic Period Obsidian Procurement in Central Mexico: A Compositional Study Using Laser Ablation-Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometry. Latin American Antiquity 18(1):27-43."

Source.Common.Name: Rancho Tenango
Geology: "Tulancingo obsidian is found in several extensive flows, and outcrops are typically exposed on hillsides and rivercuts. The material is typically grey green, but other colors are possible (Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."
Ethnominerology: "The use of this glass peaked during the Postclassic Period, as it was the primary source of obsidian for the 'Triple Allience military expansion through Tulancingo due to its strategic location on a route toward he Gulf of Mexico' (Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."

Source.Common.Name: Lake Nicaragua
Geology: "The northeast shores of Lake Nicaragua contain obsidian pebbles and nodules, and are believed to compose a unique source (Sheets et al. 1990)."

Source.Common.Name: Luisitio
Geology: "Obsidian from Luisitio is known from several small obsidian nodules in a streambed, near its town namesake. This source is not known from any archaeological contexts (Aggen 2007)."

Source.Common.Name: Batza Tena
Geology: "Batza Tena obsidian can be found in the debris of a rhyolitic lava flow between the Indian and Little Indian rivers in the Koyukuk Valley (Macdonald et al. 1992)."

Source.Common.Name: Novarupta
Geology: "Novarupta glass can be found in a lava dome in the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes, Alaska (Macdonald et al. 1992)."

Source.Common.Name: NE Umnak
Geology: "Obsidian from northeast Umnak Island is slightly hydrated microvesicular glass from a lava dome (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: SW Umnak
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Recheshnoi (Macdonald et al. 1992)."

Source.Common.Name: Okmok Caldera
Geology: "Okmok obsidian is from an 'agglutinate lava, (on the) northwest slope of Somma I of Okmok caldera, northwest Umnak Island' (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Ptarnigan Lake
Geology: "Ptarnigan Lake obsidian comes from a lava flow on the northeast side of the lake, in the form of an Apache Tear (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Capitol Mountain
Geology: "Capitol Mountain obsidian is porphyritic, and from a strongly annealed section on the southeast lava flow (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Black Tank
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Black Tank obsidian is located north of Round Mountain (within the Mount Floyd Volcanic Field) in Arizona. Nodules are small (less than five cm), range from black to mahogany, and are not abundant in the area - representing a relatively small obsidian source (Shackley 1995)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Rose Well (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior

Source.Common.Name: Annadel
Geology: "The Annadel source is located in Annadel State Park, California. It was widely exploited, and the area still bears evidence of quarrying. Obsidian from this source is small, and usually has a matrix of deeply weathered brecciated perlite. The obsidian is typically a matte luster, gray-black with a brown tint, and occasionally distinct banding (Jackson 1989)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Annadel Farms and Annadel State Park (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Source.Common.Name: Backbone Ridge variety 4
Geology: "Backbone Ridge obsidians are large, can be red, black, or clear nodules that may exhibit mahogany characteristics (Moore 2009)."
Ethnominerology: "There are four known subsources: Seaman Gulch 1, Seaman Gulch 2, Section 26, and Quarry Workshop (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Quarry Workshop (Moore 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: Bodie Hills
Geology: "The Bodie Hills source is located about 12 km east of Bridgeport, California. Raw obsidian and quarrying debris is distributed across a wide area, and includes many varieties of obsidian. The Pine Grove Hills is an additional source locality in western Nevada approximately 45 km northeast of Bridgeport, providing small cobbles (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Pine Grove Hills (Nevada) (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Borax Lake
Geology: "Borax Lake obsidian is highly variable both in glass quality and form. It ranges from pumiceous material to dense glass, and can be a dense, dark grey-black to a gray appearance containing many vesicles (Jackson 1989)."

Source.Common.Name: Bristol Mountains
Geology: "The Bristol Mountains are located southwest of the Mojave National Preserve in California with a primary source of a Miocene rhyolite dome complex, however the domes are heavily eroded and most obsidian is known from secondary deposits. Nodules can be found in sizes up to seven cm (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "The obsidian from the Bristol Mountains is typically a translucent grey, sometimes banded, and high quality tool material (Shackley 1995)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Amboy Crater and Bagdad (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Buck Mountain
Geology: "Buck Mountain obsidian can be found at the top of a hill to the northeast of the range. The glass is red-black, black, and purple in color (Moore 2009). The Pink Lady outcrop is an iridescent silver-green with a green sheen (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Davis Creek, Lassen Creek, Lodgepole, Middle Fork, Needle Grass Spring Junction, Nelson Quarry, North Fork, Pink Lady, and Tick Rise (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Burdell Mountain
Geology: "The obsidian from Burdell Mountain is found from highly weathered outcrops to the southwest of the mountain. Obsidian here is a glassy black with 'A nearly equal volume of crystalline inclusions, primarily feldspar.' Obsidian nodules are distributed across an area of 20 square meters, and there is no evidence of quarrying (Jackson 1989)."
Ethnominerology: "Obsidian from Burdell Mountain is not tool quality, nor is there any evidence of manufacturing or use (Jackson 1989)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Jackson, Thomas L. 1989. Late Prehistoric Obsidian Production and Exchange in the North Coast Ranges, California. Contributions of the Archaeological Research Facility 48:79-94."

Source.Common.Name: Casa Diablo Prospect Ridge subsource
Geology: "Casa Diablo is one of the largest sources of obsidian in the southwest, and is located in the Long Valley Caldera, California. There are between 16-26 subsources found over 65 square km, all of varying sizes and color. Obsidian here is primarily in the form of cobbles and boulders, reaching as large as one meter in length. Textures of Casa Diablo are glassy, but may exhibit fine-grained surfaces with occasional phenocryst inclusions (Giambastiani 2004)."
Ethnominerology: "There are four major outcrops used historically: Lookout Mountain, Dry Creek Canyon, Sawmill Ridge, and Obsidian Hill (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Casa Diablo, Hot Creek, and Prospect Ridge (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Coso: Joshua Ridge
Geology: "The Coso Volcanic Field lies in the Coso Range of California - and is the largest source of obsidian in eastern California, covering almost 80 square km. Obsidian from Coso Mountains typically has many vesicles, internal gas bubbles, and can appear 'foamy' depending on the size of the bubbles. Artifact-quality material can be found from the lag and colluvial deposits from flow breccia throughout the area (Giambastiani 2004)."
Ethnominerology: "Historically, the main source of the Coso Range has been Sugarloaf Mountain, but there are several notable primary sources: Cactus Peak, West Sugarloaf, and Joshua Ridge. There are also many secondary deposits with easy access, generally in the forms of cobbles and pebbles - while larger boulders can be found and mined. The clear and non-vesicular obsidian outcrops were most-often selected for tool production (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Coso, Coso Volcanic Field, Joshua Ridge, Joshua Ridge, and Coso Volcanic Field (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Draucker, Anne Christine. 2007. Geochemical Characterization of Obsidian Subsources from the Coso Range, California Using Laser Abalation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry as a Tool from Archaeological Investigations, California State University."

Geology: "The Coso Volcanic Field lies in the Coso Range of California - and is the largest source of obsidian in eastern California, covering almost 80 square km. Obsidian from Coso Mountains typically has many vesicles, internal gas bubbles, and can appear 'foamy' depending on the size of the bubbles. Artifact-quality material can be found from the lag and colluvial deposits from flow breccia throughout the area (Giambastiani 2004)."
Ethnominerology: "Historically, the main source of the Coso Range has been Sugarloaf Mountain, but there are several notable primary sources: Cactus Peak, West Sugarloaf, and Joshua Ridge. There are also many secondary deposits with easy access, generally in the forms of cobbles and pebbles - while larger boulders can be found and mined. The clear and non-vesicular obsidian outcrops were most-often selected for tool production (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Coso, Coso Volcanic Field, West Cactus Peak, West Cactus Peak, and Coso Volcanic Field (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Cougar Butte
Geology: "The Medicine Lake Highland is a large Pleistocene shield volcano, containing Holocene silicic rhyolite glass flows. The shield volcano contains several subsources, all of different composition and ages, including Cougar Butte, East Glass Mountain, Medicine Lake, Grasshopper Flat, and the Lost Iron Wells source (Hughes 1982). Obsidian from Cougar Butte is large (20cm), milky-grey, and has a pink-purple cast (Moore 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: Cowhead Lake
Geology: "Cowhead Lake obsidian can be black, grey, and purple-black from the southern portion of Cowhead Lake, California (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Bidwell Mountain, Bidwell Mountain (Cowhead Lake), Eightmile Creek, and Schadler Ditch (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: East Medicine Lake
Geology: "The Medicine Lake Highland is a large Pleistocene shield volcano, containing Holocene silicic rhyolite glass flows. The shield volcano contains several subsources, all of different composition and ages, including Cougar Butte, East Glass Mountain, Medicine Lake, Grasshopper Flat, and the Lost Iron Wells source (Hughes 1982). The glass is grey and black (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Medicine Lake Highland, Stoney Rhyolite Core, Yellowjacket, and Medicine Lake Glass Flow (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Fish Springs
Geology: "The Fish Springs source is limited to a small perlite dome in the southern Owens Valley, California. The dome protrudes from a broad alluvial fan formation, at about 1500 m asl. A large quantity of obsidian material has been carried down stream, while obsidian pebbles and cobbles can still be found at the dome (Giambastiani 2004)"
Ethnominerology: "Fish Springs obsidian is known for its greenish cast, and feathered brown inclusions - making it distinguishable from many other Inyo-Mono glasses (Giambastiani 2004)."

Source.Common.Name: Franz Valley
Geology: "Franz Valley obsidian nodules are small, and distributed over 500 square meters in the Devil's Kitchen area. Obsidian is a vitreous green-brown color, but can be found in black and grey. Although very similar, 'Franz Valley obsidian is chemically differentiated from Napa Valley obsidians by barium element concentrations in excess of 600 ppm' (Jackson 1989)."
Ethnominerology: "Franz Valley obsidian is used rather sparingly in the southern North Coast Ranges (Jackson 1989)."

Source.Common.Name: Kelly Mountain
Geology: "Kelly Mountain produces poor obsidian with many vesicles and inclusions (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Mosquito Springs and Wolverine Creek Tuff (IAOS World Source Catalog and Leeman 1982)."
