Source.Common.Name: Los Guilicos A
Geology: "Los Guilicos sources are found on the southern portion of Annadel State Park, California. Los Guilicos A is a 'dull, greasy luster and typically gray to gray-green color. This obsidian generally lacks any inclusions.' The nodules are very small, and there is no evidence of quarrying (Jackson 1989)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Guilicos A and Oakmont (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Jackson, Thomas L. 1989. Late Prehistoric Obsidian Production and Exchange in the North Coast Ranges, California. Contributions of the Archaeological Research Facility 48:79-94."

Source.Common.Name: Los Guilicos B
Geology: "Los Guilicos sources are found on the southern portion of Annadel State Park, California. Los Guilicos B obsidian typically exhibits 'a brilliant luster, numerous phenocrysts, and a black color in reflected light.. Los Guilicos B has a very definite green color.' This variety is very small, and has little evidence of quarrying (Jackson 1989)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Guilicos B and Oakmont (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Jackson, Thomas L. 1989. Late Prehistoric Obsidian Production and Exchange in the North Coast Ranges, California. Contributions of the Archaeological Research Facility 48:79-94."

Source.Common.Name: Mono Craters
Geology: "The Mono Crater source is found within an arc of late Holocene volcanic cones to the south of Mono Lake, California. It is accepted that Panum crater is the primary source of obsidian, as it is in large supply and easily accessible. Within the crater obsidian can be found in large sheets, with large cobbles in the surrounding colluvial deposits. Mono Craters deposits are typically semi-translucent to black, but 'has a greyish tint produced by the near homogeneous blending of minute white and black threadlike bands' (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Panum Crater and Inyo Craters (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Mono Glass Mountain Group General
Geology: "Mono Glass Mountain obsidian deposits can be found at the crest of Glass Mountain, at an elevation of 3390 m asl, northeast of Long Valley, California. To the west lies the Glass Mountain Ridge, a steep-sided formation at the northern edge of the caldera. Due to a past eruption, secondary sources of obsidian can be found two to three miles out to the east and northeast of the ridge, while the alluvial outwash is composed of many cobbles of low-quality obsidian (Giambastiani 2004)."
Ethnominerology: "Mono Glass mountain obsidians come in a variety of forms, ranging from red, brown, mahogany, and black - with the occasional porphyritic nodules. Obsidian from the peak is described as a translucent black with black bands, as well as opaque blacks with white inclusions, with occasional lacy patterns, phenocrysts, and some mahogany varieties (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Glass Mountain (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Mount Konocti
Geology: "Mount Konocti obsidian is of a poor quality, containing many phenocrysts. Glass can be found in colors of grey, black-brown, and red-brown (Jackson 1989)."
Ethnominerology: "Although it was fairly brittle, Mount Konocti obsidian is a common tool material in the North Coast Ranges (Jackson 1989)."

Source.Common.Name: Napa Valley
Geology: "Napa Valley obsidian comes from the Glass Mountain, in the northern Napa Valley, California. Glass from this source is an opaque black, and typically free of inclusions. Some samples may be grey and red, and contain streaks of red-brown banding (Jackson 1989)."
Ethnominerology: "The Napa Valley source is highly exploited, the mountain side is littered with knapping sites, and makes for an excellent tool material (Jackson 1989)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Blossom Creek, Crystal Summit, Meg's Crown, and Napa Glass Mountain (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Saline Range Variety 1
Geology: "The Saline Range is composed of a volcanic tableland, separating the Saline Valley from Eureka Valley in California. The obsidian nodules found here are eroded out from rhyolitic flows and tuffs, mixing into alluvial deposits and transported as far away as 20 km. Primary outcrops for Saline Ranges 1, 2, and 3 can often be found in close proximity to each other on the east side of the ridge. The Queen Impostor source, Saline Valley 1, occurs in sizes ranging from pebbles to boulders. Obsidian sources here exhibit a high degree of translucency with a gold-brown cast, occasionally containing tight, parallel black banding - very similar in appearance to Truman-Queen glass, hence the name Queen Impostor (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Dry Mountain, Queen Impostor, and Saline Valley 1 (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Sugar Hill
Geology: "Sugar Hills obsidian is found in small outcrops in devitrified ash, and is a black to pink-black material (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Junction, North Cottonwood Flat, Sugarhill, and Upper Ross (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Trinity
Geology: "Trinity obsidian can be found in the eroded base of the rhyolite flows on the eastern side of the Sonoma Valley, California. Obsidian from here is black, containing elongated phenocrysts, and has a metallic sheen. Banding is common, and most samples have a matte luster and a golden-brown tint to them. Most nodules are less than 15cm in diameter (Jackson 1989)."

Source.Common.Name: Tuscan
Geology: "Tuscan obsidian is grey banded and mahogany material found in the stream channel of Cow Creek, California (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Backbone Ridge-Cow Creek, Backbone Ridge, Cow Creek, Source X, and Tuscan (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Casa Diablo Group General
Geology: Casa Diablo is one of the largest sources of obsidian in the southwest, and is located in the Long Valley Caldera, California. There are between 16-26 subsources found over 65 square km, all of varying sizes and color. Obsidian here is primarily in the form of cobbles and boulders, reaching as large as one meter in length. Textures of Casa Diablo are glassy, but may exhibit fine-grained surfaces with occasional phenocryst inclusions (Giambastiani 2004).
Ethnominerology: There are four major outcrops used historically: Lookout Mountain, Dry Creek Canyon, Sawmill Ridge, and Obsidian Hill (Giambastiani 2004).

Source.Common.Name: Coso Group General
Geology: "The Coso Volcanic Field lies in the Coso Range of California - and is the largest source of obsidian in eastern California, covering almost 80 square km. Obsidian from Coso Mountains typically has many vesicles, internal gas bubbles, and can appear 'foamy' depending on the size of the bubbles. Artifact-quality material can be found from the lag and colluvial deposits from flow breccia throughout the area (Giambastiani 2004)."
Ethnominerology: "Historically, the main source of the Coso Range has been Sugarloaf Mountain, but there are several notable primary sources: Cactus Peak, West Sugarloaf, and Joshua Ridge. There are also many secondary deposits with easy access, generally in the forms of cobbles and pebbles - while larger boulders can be found and mined. The clear and non-vesicular obsidian outcrops were most-often selected for tool production (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Coso, Coso Volcanic Field, West Sugarloaf, and Coso Volcanic Field (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Sugarloaf Southeast
Geology: "The Coso Volcanic Field lies in the Coso Range of California - and is the largest source of obsidian in eastern California, covering almost 80 square km. Obsidian from Coso Mountains typically has many vesicles, internal gas bubbles, and can appear 'foamy' depending on the size of the bubbles. Artifact-quality material can be found from the lag and colluvial deposits from flow breccia throughout the area (Giambastiani 2004)."
Ethnominerology: "Historically, the main source of the Coso Range has been Sugarloaf Mountain, but there are several notable primary sources: Cactus Peak, West Sugarloaf, and Joshua Ridge. There are also many secondary deposits with easy access, generally in the forms of cobbles and pebbles - while larger boulders can be found and mined. The clear and non-vesicular obsidian outcrops were most-often selected for tool production (Giambastiani 2004)."

Source.Common.Name: Lost Iron Wells
Geology: "The Medicine Lake Highland is a large Pleistocene shield volcano, containing Holocene silicic rhyolite glass flows. The shield volcano contains several subsources, all of different composition and ages, including Cougar Butte, East Glass Mountain, Medicine Lake, Grasshopper Flat, and the Lost Iron Wells source (Hughes 1982)."

Source.Common.Name: American Falls
Geology: "American Falls obsidian ranges from glassy to coarse crystals, and occurs in gullies and canyons that drain into the Snake River. Nodules contain ignimbrite phenocrysts, and were created as volcanic bombs from the Owyhee Uplift (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Snake River, Walcott, and Walcott Tuff (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Blue Creek
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Blue Creek obsidian can be found in a tuff of welded ignimbrite along the southern Beaverhead Mountains through the White Knob Mountains and the northern margin of the East Snake River Plain. The glass is relatively low in phenocrysts and almost universally black (Morgan 1992)."

Source.Common.Name: Huckleberry Ridge
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian from Huckleberry Ridge is poor quality, and found on the north and south faces of the ridge (Vanwert 2000)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Mud Lake (Vanwert 2000)"
Bibliographies: "Vanwert, Kristin Ann. 2000. Variability in Flake Technology at Tree Frog, a Protohistoric Site in the Centennial Valley, Montana, University of Montana."

Source.Common.Name: Antelope Wells
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Antelope Wells obsidian source is spread over southern New Mexico and northern Chihuahua. The glass is phenocryst free, up to 10cm across, opaque green, and of excellent quality. The Antelope Wells obsidian is high in Fe content and a peralkaline source from a mid-Tertiary event (Dolan et al. 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include El Berrendo and Antelope Creek (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Obsidian Ridge
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Jemez Mountains are a broad uplift formed during the Late Tertiary and Quaternary. These mountains contain at least three subcomplexes: Bearhead Rhyolite, Paliza Canyon, and the Polvadera Canyon (Baugh 1987)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Alamo Canyon, Bearhead Peak, Cerro Toledo Rhyolite, Chapulin Canyon, Cochiti Canyon, Paso del Norte, and Rabbit Mountain (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Polvadera Peak
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Jemez Mountains are a broad uplift formed during the Late Tertiary and Quaternary. These mountains contain at least three subcomplexes: Bearhead Rhyolite, Paliza Canyon, and the Polvadera Canyon. El Rechuelos is the youngest formation in this series, and has an obsidian-bearing vent called the Polvadera Peak (Baugh 1987)."

Geology: "Badger Creek obsidian is blue-grey, and sometimes green. It is found 2.5 miles southeast of Bitner Butte, Nevada (Moore 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: C. B. Concrete
Geology: "The CB Concrete obsidian source produces small nodules in volcanic ash from a cinder cone that is currently being mined for concrete in Nevada (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes CB Concrete (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Coyote Spring
Ethnominerology: "The source of Coyote Spring use was highly localized to the High Country of northwest Nevada. The material is not a true obsidian source, and it considered a fine-grained volcanic rock (LaValley 2013)."

Source.Common.Name: Crow Spring
Geology: "The Crow Spring obsidian source lies in the Monte Cristo Range of Nevada, with obsidian nodules making up a large bulk of a perlite zone between Tertiary rhyolite flows and domes. Nodules embedded in the perlite deposits can be found in sizes ranging up to fist-sized, and nodules eroded from the perlite can be found over several acres (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "Obsidian was not widely available prehistorically from this source, and only now because of a local perlite mining operation has disturbed it. Obsidian here is a translucent mottled black containing no banding or phenocrysts (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Crow Springs and Monte Cristo (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Garfield Hills
Geology: "The Garfield Hills source is located next to Hawthorne, Nevada, and can be found in the pink rhyolite tuffs to the northern part of the hills. Obsidian nodules are most common in the alluvium (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Hawthorne (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Moore, Joe. 2009. Great Basin Tool-Stone Sources. Copies available from Nevada Department of Transportation."

Source.Common.Name: Kane Springs Wash Caldera Variety 1
Geology: "The Kane Springs Wash Caldera has a complex eruption history, located in the Delmar Mountains of Nevada. The two artifact-grade obsidian sources occur in two separate intra caldera units of early and late moat rhyolites. These units are described as having a high silica content due to the melting of the caldera walls, and the late moat rhyolite (Variety 2) contains a higher concentration of both Ba and Sr compared to the early moat (Variety 1) (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "Nodules of tool quality obsidian range from 1 to 10 cm in diameter and are available from both primary sources, as well as a wide distribution of secondary sources in the Delmar Mountains. Kane Springs obsidian is an opaque black with no inclusions (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Delamar Mountains, Kane Springs C, Kane Springs Variety C, and Kane Springs Wash Caldera Variety 1 (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Massacre Lake
Geology: "Massacre Lake obsidian is comprised of at least four different subsources, and all range from mahogany to pure black nodules, The source is scattered over 30 miles, and evidence of manufacturing and mining at the location is extensive (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Borax Works C (Oregon), Catnip Mountain, Denio, Dufferena, Grassy Ranch, Guano Slough (Oregon), Guano Valley (Oregon), Horse Canyon Spring, IXL, Massacre Creek, Nut Mountain, Sand Spring, South Hanging Rock, Stevens Camp, Virgin Valley, Windmill Quarry, and Vya (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Modena
Geology: "Obsidian from the Modena area and Panaca Summit occur over a large area, both in primary and secondary sources. Nodule sizes range from pebbles to boulders, and are usually tool quality (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Dry Valley, Panaca, Panaca Summit, and Pion Point (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Railroad Point
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Railroad Point obsidian is found in the alluvial outwash of the Virgin Creek. Tertiary volcanism produced an extensive ash deposit, and contians four glass subsources (Moore 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: Shoshone Mountain
Geology: "Shoshone Mountain is a late Miocene volcano on the southeast flank of the Timber Mountain Caldera, located approximately 35 km east of Beatty, Nevada. Obsidian can be found in sizes from 1-15 cm that are entrained in and locally weathered out of the pyroclastic flow - with high-quality obsidian being associated with the earlier-erupted tuff. Secondary sources of obsidian have been noted in the nearby alluvial terrace gravels (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "Shoshone Mountain features an abundance of local obsidian exploitation, including biface fragments, cores, and debris. Obsidian is black with uniform banding, translucent, and may contain micro-phenocrysts (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source are: Fortymile, Fortymile Wash, Lathrop Wells, Shoshone, Shoshone Peak, Topopah, Yucca Mountain, Yucca Wash, and may include Buckboard Mesa (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Geology: "The Suto Springs obsidian is found as small nodules in a cinder cone that is being mined for cement. The nodules occur in layered ash deposits (Moore 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: Double H Subsource 1
Geology: "Double H Mountains obsidian is olive green and tool quality material (Moore 2009). The McDermitt and Long Ridge Calderas formed after several events in quick succession (less than 1my) during the Mid-Miocene (Benson and Mahood 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Double H, Double H Mountain, Double H Mountains, and Whitehorse (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Double H, Double H Mountain, Double H Mountains, and Whitehorse (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Summit Lake
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Summit Lake obsidian can be found in a silicic ash-flow tuff in northwestern Nevada. Phenocrysts make up a sizeable percent in the upper and middle members of the tuff: typically pyroxene, amphibole, and biotite (Park 1983)."

Source.Common.Name: Clayton Ridge
Geology: "Clayton Ridge obsidian is found as nodules in alluvial deposits near its namesake (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: McGee Mountain
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "McGee Mountain obsidian is found in a layer of Pleistocene rhyolite welded tuff that extend east from the mountain for two miles. The tuff is heavily eroded and can liklely be attributed to a nearby vent eruption (Wendell 1970)."

Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Rocky Canyon and Rabbit Hole (Macdonald et al. 1992)."

Source.Common.Name: Tuscarora
Geology: "The Tuscarora source is from an Eocene intrusive sequence, and more specifically from one of the dacite domes it produced. Glass use has not been noted in archaeoloogical contexts (Henry and Boden 1998)."
Bibliographies: "Henry, Christopher D., and David R. Boden. 1998. Geology of the Mount Blitzen Quadrangle: Elko County, Nevada. Map 110 ed. Nevada Bureau of Mines and Geology."

Source.Common.Name: Burns
Ethnominerology: "Very large quantities of obsidian of excellent tool manufacturing quality are found at many locations in the hills north and northwest of the town of Burns and along the Silvies River drainage northeast of Burns. Characterization studies in the Burns area indicate that the obsidian was extensively used in the immediate region surrounding the sources. Although Burns obsidian is found at archaeological sites in the Malheur Lake Basin, use of the glass appears to decline rapidly with distance from the source. Artifacts correlated with the source are rarely identified outside the Harney-Malheur Basin' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Burns Baker, Burns Butte, Hines, Radar Hill, and Skull Creek (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Source.Common.Name: Chickahominy
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Ethnominerology: "Abundant nodules of high quality obsidian occur as surface float and bedrock outcrops along Chickahominy Creek in the vicinity of Chickahominy Campground. Prehistoric use of obsidian from this source appears to be rather limited and artifacts correlated with the Chickahominy source are only very occasionally identified, usually from the immediate source region' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."

Source.Common.Name: Coglan Buttes
Geology: "Coglan Butte obsidian has a purple sheen to it, and is found to the west of Lake Albert, Oregon (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Coghlan Buttes (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Cougar Mountain
Geology: "This prominent obsidian and rhyolite dome is the source of large quantities of high quality black and occasionally gray obsidian. The dome is located at the northern edge of the Fort Rock Valley and the northern margin of Pluvial Fort Rock Lake. Small nodules of glass from Cougar Mountain are also found in lake deposits in much of this large Pleistocene lake basin' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."
Ethnominerology: "Tools from this source may be found as far north as the Klamath Basin, and into the Cascades as well (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."

Source.Common.Name: Dog Hill
Geology: "High quality glass occurs as surface float over a wide area about 15-20 km northwest of Burns, Oregon. Small nodules of obsidian from this source have also been identified in secondary gravel deposits in the Harney-Malheur Basin as far south as Wrights Point. The glass occasionally occurs in a very distinctive green color (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Burn's Green (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."

Source.Common.Name: Silver Lake
Geology: "Silver Lake and Sycan Marsh obsidian is black, faintly banded, and rarely contains phenocrysts. Yamsay Mountain produces two obsidian domes, although both have been partially covered by more recent flows. Secondary outcrops of obsidian are scattered throughout the region, and nodule can be found in alluvial gravel deposits (Thatcher 2000)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Carlon Ranch, Long Creek, Silver Lake/Sycan Marsh North, Silver Lake/Sycan Marsh South, Sycan Marsh, Yamsay Mountain, and Mount Mazama (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Beatys Butte Group General
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology:
"Dense concentrations of surface nodules covering several square kilometers are found on the lower northern,
eastern, and western slopes of Beatys Butte and are common in the lacustrine deposits of Pluvial Lake Catlow
to the north and east of the butte. Obsidian from this source was widely used in the Steens Mountain area and
the southeastern portion of the state and has been identified as far north as the Malheur National Forest and as
far west as the southern Oregon coast' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Beaty's Butte and Beatty's Butte (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Glass Buttes Group General
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Nine geochemically distinct sources of obsidian are found in association with the Glass Buttes source complex that is located immediately south of Highway 20 in northeastern Lake County.. Secondary deposits of obsidian from this and most other Glass Buttes geochemical source groups occur throughout the basin lying north of the source and in the basin located south of the complex' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."
Ethnominerology: "Although obsidian from all of the identified Glass Buttes sources was primarily used in the immediate region surrounding the source complex, glass from the source area has been identified in archaeological sites to the north in Washington and British Columbia, Canada, and as far west as the Western Cascades of Oregon and the Portland Basin' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Glass Butte Crescent (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Pumice Hole Mine Group General
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Mineral Mountains are composed of lava domes, flows, and tuffs from 500,000 to 800,000 years ago. These mountains have three distinct rhyolite sequences, with obsidian being found in the lower two: Wildhorse Canyon and Pumice Hole (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Mineral Mountains and Mineral Mountain Range (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Topaz Mountain
Geology: "Topaz Mountain rhyolite erupted between 7 and 6 million years ago, and the nodules can be found up to 15 cm across (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "The Topaz Mountain source was commonly used to fashion artifacts found in the southern Great Salt Lake Desert and Tule Valley regions of northwestern Utah, and this glass type dominates Paleo Archaic flaked stone tool assemblages in the Wildcat Mountain area' (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Thomas Range (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Mineral Mountains composed of lava domes, flows, and tuffs from 500,000 to 800,000 years ago. The Mineral Mountains have three distinct rhyolite sequences, with obsidian being found in the lower two: Wildhorse Canyon and Pumice Hole sources. The Wildhorse Canyon flows contain blocks of obsidian up to a half meter across (Haarklau et al. 2005)."

Source.Common.Name: Washington State General Proxy
Loc..Notes: THIS IS NOT AN OBSIDIAN SOURCE
Geology: "The Juan de Fuca plate is subducting under the North American Plate and creating the Cascades, as the oceanic crust rises through the continental crust. Because there are few reports publishing geochemical sources in Washington State, data from marine glass deposits are provided as a proxy for the northern Cascade Mountains."
Ethnominerology: "The data provided for this conclusion has no terrestrial deposits and is used specifically to approximate for the missing Washington data."
Bibliographies: "Eaby, Jacqueline, David Clague, and John R. Delaney. 1984. Sr Isotopic Variations Along the Juan de Fuca Ridge. Journal of Geophysical Research 89(B9):7883-7890. "

Source.Common.Name: Fishing Bridge
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Fishing Bridge obsidian is a fractured black obsidian vitrophyre with slight pitchstone luster bordering fractures from the Elephant Back Flow, Yellowstone National Park. It contains a moderate amount of phenocrysts, typically quartz, sanidine, and other accessory minerals (Christiansen 2001)."

Source.Common.Name: Grassy Lake Reservoir
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Grassy Lake obsidian can be found in a columnar zone along Lava Creek Tuff quarries that are widely exposed in and around Yellowstone National Park and extending into the Snake River Plain. Deposits are noted for having a blue to purplish hue to them. Phenocrysts of quartz, sanidine, and other minerals are common (Christiansen 2001)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Grassy Lake and Lava Creek Tuff (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Obsidian Cliff
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian Cliff is known for producing black obsidian with few or no phenocrysts, in stark contrast to most obsidian sources from the Yellowstone Hotspot (Christiansen 2001)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include F.M.Y. 150 Group, Obsidian Cliffs (commonly used erroneous name), and Yellowstone Cliff (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Alcedo
Geology: "Obsidian from Alcedo can be found on the southeast caldera floor, rim, and flanks. The glass often contains phenocrysts (Macdonald et al. 1992)."
Bibliographies: "Global Volcanism Program, 2013. 2013. Volcanoes of the World v. 4.6.2, http://dx.doi.org/10.5479/si.GVP.VOTW4-2013, Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC. ; Macdonald, R., R. L. Smith, and J. E. Thomas. 1992. Chemisty of Subalkalic Silicic Obsidians. U. S. Geological Survey Professional Papers 1523."

Source.Common.Name: Gaua
Geology: "Obsidian from Gaua can be found on the northeast interior of the caldera, close to the rim. Nodules can also be found in alluvial deposits from the rim down to Losalava Bay, and are scattered throughout the slopes. Gaua obsidian is known for being high quality for tool making (Summerhayes 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: Vanua Lava
Geology: "Vanua Lava obsidian deposits are found northwest of Losa Bay at sea level, with nodules scattered across the beach and in nearby river streams. Additional deposits of both obsidian and other volcanic glasses have been alleged to exist throughout the island, but have not been confirmed nor have they been found in archaeological contexts. The quality of the glass varies, but is typically vesicular (Summerhayes 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: Kilauea
Geology: "Kilauea obsidian is blue, dense, and sparsely vesicular. Glass from this source is typically found 'On low-relief lava fields at the base of tumuli or associated with waning and collapsed lava tubes.' The outer blue ring weathers away quickly, so most obsidian is black with only a blue tint (Lundblad et al)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Geological Society of America 104(11):1471-1484."

Source.Common.Name: Mauna Loa
Geology: "'Mauna Loa surface flows can be found throughout the Kona and South Kohala Districts' meaning the glass is well distributed throughout the island. The outer blue ring weathers away quickly, so most obsidian is black with only a blue tint (Lundblad et al)."

Source.Common.Name: Puu Waawaa
Geology: "Puu Waawaa obsidian can be found as small nodules that were 'formed as a result of trachyte eruptions from the Hualalai Volcano which occurred between the end of tholeiitic basaltic volcanism and the onset of alkalic basaltic volcanism' (Lundblad et al)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Puu Waawaa (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Loc..Notes: Location of Source is unknown probably in Pago Caldera of Tutuila Island American Samoa (Goat island is passed Observation Point in the Pago Pago Harbour?)
Geology: "Obsidian can be found in the Pago Caldera on the Tutuila Island of American Samoa, but more specifically on Goat Island which is out passed Observation Point in Pago Pago Harbour (Sheppard 1989)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Tutuila and American Samoa (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Archaeology in Oceania 24:70-74."

Source.Common.Name: Archibarca
Geology: "Archibarca obsidian outcrops lie 100 km northwest of Antofagasta de la Sierra, and is mainly found in secondary alluvial deposits. The glass is opaque black with gray banding, and often found as large nodules (Escola et al. 2016)."

Source.Common.Name: Cueros de Purulla
Geology: "Cueros de Purulla outcrops are located 60-70 km southwest of Antofagasta de la Sierra. The glass may be found in large blocks exceeding 25 centimeters in length, and range from black to black-red. 'In this regard, it must be noted that black obsidian corresponds to opaque shiny volcanic glass and dark gray and black-reddish to an opaque satin one' (Escola et al. 2016)."

Source.Common.Name: Cueva del Huenul
Geology: "Cueva del Huenul obsidian is from an area below the Headwaters of the Colorado River in Argentina. Glass from this source is distributed between several volcanos, and may be up to 80 cubic cm (Duran et al. 2011)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Cerro Huenul (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: El Peceo-1
Geology: "The obsidian source known as Cerro el Peceo is from El Nevada Volcano, a relatively small cone with many alluvial deposits. Nodules from this source vary in size, up to 30cm across (Duran et al. 2011). Being on the Eastern Plains of Southern Mendoza, this source was easily accesible and has been exploited historically. Samples from El Peceo-2 are more likely to be found in the alluvial deposits than El Peceo-1 (Salgn and Pompeo 2017)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Cerro el Peceo 1 (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Laguna del Diamante Arroyo las Numeradas subsource
Geology: "Laguna del Diamante obsidian is found in the Cordillera Principal Volcanic Complex, near the a lagoon and river of the same name. There are two subsources: Arroyo las Numeradas and Arroyo Paramillos. Arroyo Las Numerals is widely distributed within the caldera along the crests and ridges, as well as the surrounding valleys (Duran et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Laguna del Diamante Arroyo Paramillos subsource
Geology: "Laguna del Diamante obsidian is found in the Cordillera Principal Volcanic Complex, near the a lagoon and river of the same name. There are two subsources: Arroyo las Numeradas and Arroyo Paramillos. Arroyo Paramillos obsidian can be found only in the glacial and alluvial deposits near the caldera. Typically, Arroyo Paramillos nodules are less than 3 cm across (Duran et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Las Cargas
Geology: "Arroyo de las Cargas obsidian is found in the Planchn-Peteroa Volcanic Complex, on the border of Argentina and Chile. Nodules are distributed across an area of 8 square km, and secondary deposits can be found for many km around due to glaciation and erosion of the volcano. This glass is of high quality, but was not widely used (Duran et al. 2011)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Arroyo de las Cargas (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Pampa del Asador 1
Geology: "Pampa del Asador obsidian is found primarily in fluvial and glacial secondary deposits in the Santa Cruz Province of Argentina. Nodules are translucent grey to black, up to 20 cm across, and may contain a brown-grey tint in more weathered samples. Pampa del Asador varieties 1 and 2 are free of phenocrysts, while a third variety contains small plagioclase feldspar inclusions (Fernandez et al. 2015)."

Source.Common.Name: Lavras do Sul Shoshonitic Association
Geology: "Obsidian from the southernmost tip of Brazil originates 'post-collisional stage of the Brasiliano/Pan-African orogenic cycle in the Neoproterozoic III to Ordovician period.' The obsidian is dark, dense, and finely banded (Wildner et al. 2002). There is no evidence of archaeological use."
Bibliographies: "Wilder, W., E. F. Lima, L. V. S. Nardi, and C. A. Sommer. 2002. Volcanic Cycles and Setting in the Neoproterozoic III to Ordovician Camaqua Basin Sucession in Southern Brazil: Characteristics of Post-Collisional Magmatism. Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research 118:261-283."

Source.Common.Name: Chaiten Volcano
Geology: "Chaiten Volcano obsidian is from 'A rhyolitic dome within a collapsed caldera located on the west flank of the much larger Michinmahuida volcano, northeast of the town of Chaiten.' Glass from this source is a translucent grey with bands, and contains phenocrysts of quartz and feldspar (Fernandez et al. 2015)."

Source.Common.Name: Seno Otway
Geology: "Seno de Otway obsidian is dark green to dark grey, and exhibits banding from colorless to green. 'This type of hydrated calc-alkaline obsidian has been identified solely from the analysis of artifacts found in both coastal maritime archaeological sites around the Otway Sea, the Magellan Strait and Tierra del Fuego, and, in smaller amounts, in terrestrial hunter gatherer sites in the Magellanic region' (Fernandez et al. 2015)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Seno de Otway (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Acari type
Geology: "Acari Type obsidian is known only from sites in the Acari Valley on the southern coast of Peru, and its location is assumed to be in the surrounding highlands (Asaro and Burger 1997)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Earth and Planetary Science Letters 41:175-187."

Source.Common.Name: Alca-1
Geology: "Alca obsidian was heavily used in the Department of Cuzco, and is seldom found outside of it. Its location is still unknown but assumed to be in the Southern Highlands, and it was (probably) used during the Preceramic (Asaro and Burger 1997)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Cuzco Type (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Upper Cenozoic Volcanism in the Central Andes - Ages and Volumes. Earth and Planetary Science Letters 41:175-187."

Source.Common.Name: Chivay
Geology: "Chivay obsidian is common in sites across northern Bolivia and southern Peru, although the location of the source is unknown. 'Unworked obsidian of this type was found near the modern town of Llalli, Melgar Province Department of Puno' (Asaro and Burger 1997).  "
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Cotallalli and Titicaca Basin type (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Jampatilla
Geology: "Jampatilla obsidian was used commonly used in sites from the Cabana Sur and Andamarca area of southern Ayacucho (Asaro and Burger 1997). This glass is high quality, varies from transparent to black, and often has irregular streaks and patches of black in clear areas. The location is '3-4 km to the east-northeast of the town of Huaycahuacho, Lucanas Province, Department of Ayacucho' (Burger et al. 1998)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Pampas type (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Lisahuacho
Geology: "Lisahuacho obsidian is 'Heavily represented at sites in the Andahuaylas area' and presumed to be local. The glass was significant during the Initial Period to Early Intermediate Periods (Asaro and Burger 1997)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Andahuaylas type A (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Potreropampa
Geology: "Potreropampa obsidian is known from only three sites, and all of them are in the Andahuaylas region. 'Almost all of the Andahuaylas B Type obsidian is either found associated with Waywaka Phase occupation (early Late Intermediate Period), in mixed material, or on the surface of late material' (Asaro and Burger 1997)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Andahuaylas type B (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Quispisisa
Geology: "Quispisisa obsidian can be found in volcanic flows at the headwaters of the Pisco River, in the highlands above San Genero, Castrovirreyna Province, Department of Huancavelica, Peru. Glass from Quispisisa ranges from black to clear, but on occasion may be red or red speckled (Asaro and Burger 1997)."
Ethnominerology: "Quispisisa obsidian was very widely used in Peru, with use starting from the Preceramic and traded as far north as Huancayo. The outcrop was heavily mined as was easily transported via the Pisco River, '..The long distance movement of its obsidian constitutes some of the earliest concrete evidence of interzonal and interregional travel and exchanges in the Andes' (Asaro and Burger 1997)."

Source.Common.Name: Cerros del Ro
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The (Cerros del Ro) quarry occupies a 2- to 2.5-m thick, horizontal zone of black, massive [dacite] that forms the base of a thick Cerros del Ro lava flow exposed in a small butte near the Ro Grande.' Obsidian from here is a glassy black, and of high quality (Shackley 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Zaragoza Potreros Caldera subsource
Geology: "Zaragoza glass is opaque and dense black, may contain particulates, and exhibits lateral banding of dark-grey to black. The flows are several meters thick (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Zaragoza obsidian was heavily exploited and used during the Formative Period, and it is common in lithic assemblages. Mines and workshops can be found in the southern deposits, while the northern ones appear untouched (Doering 2002)."

Source.Common.Name: Mt. Edziza Group General
Geology: "Mount Edziza is a large stratovolcano with most obsidian quarries occurring at elevations of 1800-2000 m asl. Obsidian can be found at lower elevations and in the surrounding river systems, but it is less culturally valuable (Reimer 2015)."
Ethnominerology: "Cultural use of Mount Edziza obsidian was found throughout the coast and local river systems. There are a total of 10 distinct obsidian flows, although only 3 have been used historically (Goat Mountain, Pyramid Mountain, and Sorcery Ridge). Mount Edziza is at the center of the Tahltan First Nation territory, and its obsidian is not common in neighboring groups (Reimer 2015)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Coffee Crater, Fan Creek, Goat Mountain, Pyramid, and Sorcery Ridge (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. Source.Common.Name: San Antonio Mountains
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "San Antonio Mountain is a late Pliocene dacite shield volcano in the western Taos Plateau, New Mexico. Obsidian from this source is a glassy dark grey and contains a few feldspar phenocrysts. Nodules may be found in situ up to 50 cm in diameter, and quality varies greatly within the source (Shackley 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Sierra Fresnal East
Geology: "Sierra Fresnal is located in northern Chihuahua, and can be found in secondary alluvial deposits for 70 km around (Dolan et al. 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source includes Lago Fredrico, Laguna Azteca, and Ojo Fredrico (Dolan et al. 2017, Shackley 2002)."

Source.Common.Name: Laguna del Maule-2 Santiago
Geology: "Obsidian from Laguna del Maule comes from the border of Argentina and Chile, as part of the Cordillera Principal Volcanic Complex. Nodules range from 3-5 cm and are heterogenous in composition (Duran et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Box Spring Monitor Valley
Geology: "The Box Spring source of obsidian is located at the northern end of the Monitor Playa and can be found in alluvial deposits and streambeds at the base of the Toquima Range. Nodules here are no larger than 3 cm, and originated from a volcanic butte 5 km east of Box Spring, Nevada (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Box Springs (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Glass Buttes 5
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "'Nine geochemically distinct sources of obsidian are found in association with the Glass Buttes source complex that is located immediately south of Highway 20 in northeastern Lake County.. Secondary deposits of obsidian from this and most other Glass Buttes geochemical source groups occur throughout the basin lying north of the source and in the basin located south of the complex' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."
Ethnominerology: "'Although obsidian from all of the identified Glass Buttes sources was primarily used in the immediate region surrounding the source complex, glass from the source area has been identified in archaeological sites to the north in Washington and British Columbia, Canada, and as far west as the Western Cascades of Oregon and the Portland Basin' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Glass Buttes E, Potato Hills, and Wise Flat (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Palo Gordo
Geology: "Palo Gordo obsidian can be found in several deposits on the Tajumulco Volcano (Cobean et al. 1991). Although it was heavily exploited, this material is actually an ignimbrite and not obsidian (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Archaeological use spans Formative sites in the immediate area south to the Oaxacan Isthmus occupations, Paleoindian sites in the highlands, and Archaic Pacific Coast sites (Cobean et al. 1991)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Tajumulco-1 and San Marcos (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Sansare
Geology: "Sansare obsidian is found on a flat mesa top - and secondarily on its slopes - 2 km to the southeast of Sansare, in the Guatemalan Highlands. The source was greatly exploited by locals during the Middle Formative Period, but use of other sources became prominent in later periods. Glass from Sansare is variable in quality (Braswell and Glascock 1992)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Braswell, Geoffery E., and Michael D. Glascock. 1992. Volcanoes of the World v. 4.6.2, http://dx.doi.org/10.5479/si.GVP.VOTW4-2013, Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC."

Source.Common.Name: Devil Peak West
Geology: "The Devil Peak obsidian source is located in the southern Spring Mountains, Nevada.Obsidian occurs on both sides of the peak in perlite and vitrophyre, within a series of coalesced Tertiary domes of rhyolite. The east and west deposits are chemically distinct and 5 km apart (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "Manufacturing of both East and West varieties can be found on the peak and in the surrounding secondary deposits. Devil Peak West is thought to be a higher quality and larger nodule source of obsidian than the East. Devil Peak obsidian is a translucent black with occasional bubbles and banding (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Devil Peak and Umpire (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Shackley, Steven M. n. d. Devil peak, Clark County. 2017."

Source.Common.Name: Double H
Geology: "Double H Mountains obsidian is olive green and tool quality material (Moore 2009). The McDermitt and Long Ridge Calderas formed after several events in quick succession (less than 1my) during the Mid-Miocene (Benson and Mahood 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Double H, Double H Mountain, Double H Mountains, and Whitehorse (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Shirin Boulag
Geology: "Shirin Boulag obsidian is found on the southeastern face of Bozgoush Mountain. The glass is poor quality, green, and typically found as small nodules (Niknami et al. 2010)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source is Bozgoush Mountain (Niknami et al. 2010)."

Source.Common.Name: La Chimba
Geology: "Dyrdahl and Speakman 2013 'tentatively treat the one La Chimba type signature that appears to have the same chemical signature as a section of the Callejones source area as a 'low Fe variant of Callejones.' Meanwhile, the remaining La Chimba type signature from a source area of unknown origin is referred to as the 'La Chimba type.''"

Source.Common.Name: Chogabon Site
Loc..Notes: LOCATION IS UNKNOWN AND APPROXIMATED - location is archaeological site
Geology: "The source and location for this obsidian are unknown, but it is believed to represent a geochemically unique deposit in Iran (Nadooshan et al. 2010)."
Bibliographies: "Nadooshan, Farhang Khademi, Mohd Ayvatwand, H. Geghanifar, Michael D. Glascock, and S. Colby Phillips. 2010. Report on the Chogabon SIte, a New Source of Obsidian Artifacts in West-Central Iran. IAOS Bulletin 42:9-12. "

Source.Common.Name: San Martn Jilotepeque 5
Geology: "San Martn obsidian is dark grey with possible irregular black banding, but frequently has particulates that can give it an overall red-brown hue. The quality of this glass is highly variable. Inclusions are common from dust to sand grain size and can occur in cloud-like formations (Doering 2002). Deposits are typically difficult to reach and are exposed on the banks of the Pixcay River (Stross et al. 1983). San Martn Jilotepeque 5 origintates from a small rhyolite dome to the southeast of the complex (Braswell and Glascock 1998)."
Ethnominerology: "Use of this source peaked during the Middle Formative period, when it became the dominant material throughout the Mayan Lowlands and the Chiapas Highlands (Doering 2002)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Aldea, Chatalun, Chimaltenango, Choatalum, Inyaalchay, Las Burras, Pachay, Pixcay, Ro Pixcay, and Sauces Type C (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Cow Canyon
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Cow Canyon source is eroding east into the Eagle and Blue River, south into the San Francisco River, and west into the Gila River (Shackley 1995). Samples are commonly brown-green, and may exhibit light banding (Shackley 2005)."

Geology: "This source is alleged to be located above the Gulf of Oman, currently bears no name, and it has not been archaeologically exploited that we know of."

Source.Common.Name: Obsidian Butte Variety 5
Geology: "The Obsidian Butte Volcanic Complex contains several well known subsources, including Crow Spring, Silver Peak, the Montezuma Range, Shoshone Mountain, and Tempiute Mountain, as well as Obsidian Butte. Obsidian Butte is a black-brown and slightly translucent obsidian featuring distinct banding, spherulites, and phenocrysts (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "The Obsidian Butte Volcanic Center was commonly utilized for point manufacturing spanning the entire prehistory of the Great Basin and Mojave Desert (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include North Obsidian Butte, Obsidian Butte Area, Stonewall Canyon, and Unknown C (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Sierra Fresnal Group General
Geology: "Sierra Fresnal is located in northern Chihuahua, and can be found in secondary alluvial deposits for 70 km around (Dolan et al. 2016)."

Source.Common.Name: Sierra La Brea
Geology: "Sierra La Brea obsidian is from northwest Chihuahua, between Casas Grandes and La Cueva de la Olla. Nodules are small and can be found in situ in a perlite deposit, and have not been recorded being exploited in the past (Shackley 2005)."

Source.Common.Name: Los Vidrios
Geology: "Los Vidrios obsidian occurs in 10cm nodules, found in a series of rhyolite domes 12km south of the US-Mexican border (Shackley 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "The quality of the glass is quite good, although Los Vidrios obsidian tends to be brittle - causing bipolar reduction to result in a flaked 'explosion,' with pressure flaking being the optimal method (Shackley 2005)."

Source.Common.Name: South Kawich Range
Geology: "Volcanic rocks from the Belted Range group came from the eruption of the Grouse Canyon Caldera, roughly 13.5 to 13.85 mya. This eruption produced a tuff of densely welded ash flow with a basal vitrophyre of dense glass ranging from inches to feet thick. A secondary deposit is located on the east side of the Kawich range, producing small toolstone-quality material (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "South Kawich Range obsidian is opaque, veined, black to medium grey, and may contain air bubbles (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Apache Tear Canyon, Kawich Range, and Lgrimas de Apache (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: South Pahroc
Geology: "The South Pahroc Range forms the western boundary of Delmar and Pahroc valleys in Nevada. The range is a tilted fault block with a complex series of associated lava domes and flows. Nodules from here are normally too small for tool use, but some specimens can be larger than 5cm (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Other.Names:

Source.Common.Name: Casa Diablo Lookout Mountain subsource
Geology: "Casa Diablo is one of the largest sources of obsidian in the southwest, and is located in the Long Valley Caldera, California. There are between 16-26 subsources found over 65 square km, all of varying sizes and color. Obsidian here is primarily in the form of cobbles and boulders, reaching as large as one meter in length. Textures of Casa Diablo are glassy, but may exhibit fine-grained surfaces with occasional phenocryst inclusions (Giambastiani 2004)."
Ethnominerology: "There are four major outcrops used historically: Lookout Mountain, Dry Creek Canyon, Sawmill Ridge, and Obsidian Hill (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Casa Diablo and Lookout Mountain (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: San Juan de los Arcos
Ethnominerology: "'The source area known as San Juan de los Arcos was heavily mined during pre-Hispanic times. More than 250 mines were located with evidence of many more existing as subterranean. Massive exploitation of the high quality glass from this source is apparent. Evidence for workshops on the site is widespread with numerous basalt hammerstones and piles of waste from tool production scattered over a wide area. The source is also unique in that it was apparently used to produce large quantities of microblades, as well as extremely thin flakes used for the manufacture, by a unique technique, of the obsidian jewelry characteristic of the late Formative western Mexico' (Glascock et al. 2010)."

Source.Common.Name: Teuchitlan
Geology: "Teuchitlan obsidian is located 2 km east of La Mora, Jalisco, Mexico. The glass is high quality and black (Glascock et al. 2010)."
Ethnominerology: "Teuchitlan obsidian is '3km west of the monumental late Formative period precinct of the Guachimontones de Teuchitln, where nearby extensive workshops using this source are located.. Hammerstones, although not frequent, are found adjacent to the mines and pits' (Glascock et al. 2010)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes La Mora (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Glass Buttes 8
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "'Nine geochemically distinct sources of obsidian are found in association with the Glass Buttes source complex that is located immediately south of Highway 20 in northeastern Lake County.. Secondary deposits of obsidian from this and most other Glass Buttes geochemical source groups occur throughout the basin lying north of the source and in the basin located south of the complex' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."
Ethnominerology: "'Although obsidian from all of the identified Glass Buttes sources was primarily used in the immediate region surrounding the source complex, glass from the source area has been identified in archaeological sites to the north in Washington and British Columbia, Canada, and as far west as the Western Cascades of Oregon and the Portland Basin' (Skinner and Thatcher 2003)."

Source.Common.Name: Paredn A
Geology: "Paredn obsidian is transparent, black to grey, and may exhibit a slight beige tint. It can have 'Interior globular inclusions (0.5-1.0 mm) appearing as round-to-oblong black spheres with sharply defined edges. Smaller stipple-like particulates are common quartz-like inclusions when at the surface' (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Paredn obsidian has been exploited by Pre-Columbian groups from the Early Formative to the Late Post-Classic periods. The source can be found to the southwest of the Metzitilan Valley, and most cobbles are found in secondary fluvial deposits (Berning 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Tecocomulco (Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."

Source.Common.Name: Tempiute Mountain
Geology: "Obsidian from Tempiute Mountain come from an underlying unit on the alluvial fan of the mountain. Obsidian is a uniform black with micro-phenocrysts (Haarklau et al. 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "There is evidence of local tool manufacturing at the source of Tempiute Mountain, including bifaces and debris (Haarklau et al. 2005)."

Source.Common.Name: Saline Range Variety 2
Geology: "The Saline Range is composed of a volcanic tableland, separating the Saline Valley from Eureka Valley in California. The obsidian nodules found here are eroded out from rhyolitic flows and tuffs, mixing into alluvial deposits and transported as far away as 20 km. Primary outcrops for Saline Ranges 1, 2, and 3 can often be found in close proximity to each other on the east side of the ridge. Obsidian sources here exhibit a high degree of translucency with a gold-brown cast, occasionally containing tight, parallel black banding. Saline Ranges 2 and 3 often feature unpatterned and blotchy clouded areas (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Dry Mountain and Saline Valley 2"

Source.Common.Name: Ilhus Secos
Geology: "The Cape Verde Archipelago is the products of successive Neogene volcanics. Obsidian may possibly be present on all islands, but it has been confirmed on the island of Ilhus Secos (MItchell-Thome 1972)."

Source.Common.Name: Baltchit
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Balchit obsidian comes from Pliocene silicic activity in the Addis Ababa region of Ethiopia. Glass is grey and contains phenocrysts primarily of feldspar. Nodules can be 2-3m thick (Negash et al. 2006)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source is Group 1g (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Bora
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian from the Bora volcano in Ethiopia can either be found as fragments in breccia/pyroclast that erupted though a previous flow, or as intact flows and domes along the fault lines of the area (Korme 1999)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source may include Bora'at (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Da'Ure
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Da'Ure is a vent northeast of the Dabbahu volcano. Like the obsidian from the main volcano, it is lacking phenocrysts and formed from the the latest eruptive activity from the complex (Field et al. 2012)."

Source.Common.Name: Ficke
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Ficke obsidian deposits are found on its volcano namesake in the Main Ethiopia Rift, between Lake Abijata and Lake Shala. The glass contains abundant phenocrysts, typically sanidine, and is not commonly found in archaeological assembalges for this reason (Shacjkley and Sahale 2017).".

Source.Common.Name: Kone
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Kone obsidian comes from a large caldera complex, composed of craters and cinder cones, following the badlands. The glass is typically black but may be green (Negash and Shackley 2006)."

Source.Common.Name: Paredn B
Geology: "Paredn obsidian is transparent, black to grey, and may exhibit a slight beige tint. It can have 'Interior globular inclusions (0.5-1.0 mm) appearing as round-to-oblong black spheres with sharply defined edges. Smaller stipple-like particulates are common quartz-like inclusions when at the surface' (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Paredn obsidian has been exploited by Pre-Columbian groups from the Early Formative to the Late Post-Classic periods. The source can be found to the southwest of the Metzitilan Valley, and most cobbles are found in secondary fluvial deposits (Berning 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Tecocomulco (Pastrana and Carbollo 2017)."
Bibliographies: "Millhauser, John K., Enrique Rodrguez-Alegra, and Michael D. Glascock. 2011. Fargher, Verenice Y. Heredia Espinoza, and Richard E. Blanton. 2015. The Geopolitics of Obsidian Supply in Postclassic Tlaxcallan: A Portable X-Ray Fluorescence Study. Journal of Archaeological Science 58:133-146."

Source.Common.Name: Nabro
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior

Source.Common.Name: Dubbi
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Dubbi obsidian source can be found as nodules that are rather common across the whole volcanic complex, in close proximity to the Ado Ale source (Khalidi 2010)."

Source.Common.Name: Inman Creek B
Geology: "Inman Creek obsidian is widely distributed through alluvial means, and may be far from the outcrop. Inman Creek A has been identified at originating from Mount David Douglas, Oregon. Inman Creek B has yet to be located, but it is probably within the same vicinity. Creek B is characterized ass having lesser concentrations of Sr and Zr than Creek A (Skinner and Baxter 1997)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Bills Creek, Eagle Creek, Fern Ridge, Inman, Long Tom, Mount David Douglas, Petite Creek, Pleasant Hill, Siuslaw River, Staley Creek, Unknown D, and Willamette River Gravels (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Satanakar Group General
Geology: "The Satanakar dome volcano is ringed by obsidian flows that have all erroded into steep cliff faces with an extensive talus. The glass ranges from grey to black, may feature banding, and is of high quality. Satanakar subsource 1 is found on the southern and western flows, and Satanakar 2 is found primarily in the southeastern flows (Cherry et al. 2010)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggest alternate names for this source include Metz Satanakar and Pokr Satanakar (IAOS World Source Catalog, Chataigner and Gratuze 2014)."

Source.Common.Name: O'Leary Peak
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "O'Leary obsidian is a highly vitrophric obsidian with a low density. The material is poor for tool making, partly because of frequent ash inbanding and large phenocrysts (Shackley 2005)."

Source.Common.Name: Presley Wash
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Presley Wash obsidian is 'a gray and black glassy and subvitreous rhyolite most often opaque gray to gray-green to black. Sanidine or plagioclase phenocrysts are common in the matrix' (Shackley 1995)."
Ethnominerology: "Presley Wash obsidians range from poor to medium quality material for tool manufacturing (Shackley 1995)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR. ; Shackley, Steven M. 1995. Source.Common.Name: RS Hill
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "RS Hill is a small rhyolite dome that produces cobbles of up to 35cm across, and the glass is high quality (Shackley 2005)."

Source.Common.Name: San Francisco Peak A
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "San Francisco obsidian may be found in a large lava flow on the northwest slope. The glass is typically heavily vitrophric and contains interbanded ash layers, making it 'generally useless for biface manufacture' (Shackley 2005)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Fremont-Agassiz Saddle (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Sand Tanks
Geology: "Although this source appears not to have been exploited in the past, Sand Tank obsidian is a medium quality glass that occurs in large nodules over several rhyolite domes (Shackley 2005)."

Source.Common.Name: Sitgreaves Mountain
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Nodules of up to 20cm are common surrounding Sitgreaves Mountain. The glass is opaque grey, and contains many phenocrysts (Shackley 2005)"
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Sitgreaves Peak (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Topaz Basin
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "The Topaz Basin is a plateau remnant of Tertiary basalt and rhyolite flows. A secondary deposit can be found in the alluvium for up to 6 km away. Topaz Basin obsidian is high quality obsidian, colored transparent to smokey, rarely exhibits banding, and generally occurs in nodules less than 5 cm across (Shackley 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: Vulture
Geology: "Vulture obsidian ranges from opaque to a brown-green, and represent a high quality tool source (Shackley 2005)."
Ethnominerology: "'Vulture obsidian is common in PreClassic and Classic Period contexts in the Phoenix Basin, particularly in PreClassic sites along the Lower Salt River' (Shackley 2005)."

Source.Common.Name: Wimpilla Group General

Source.Common.Name: Yanarangra
Geology: "Yanaranga obsidian can be found about 8 km south of San Genaro, Castrovirreyna Province, Department of Huancavelica. The glass is low quality, and contains several inclusions - there is no evidence of being used for tools making (Glascock et al. 2007)."

Source.Common.Name: Jan Mayen
Geology: "Obsidian bombs are found in abundance on Jan Mayen, in the Artic Ocean (Imsland 1978)."
Bibliographies: "Imsland, Pall. 1978. The Geology of the Volcanic Island Jan Mayen Artic Ocean. Nordic Volcanological Institute, University of Iceland."

Source.Common.Name: Porto Santo
Geology: "There are thin layers of obsidian in the glassy clast breccia and the pumice-lithic breccia strata on Porto Santo, Madeira, Portugal. There is no evidence of it ever being used archaeologically (Shmidt and Schmincke 2002)."
Bibliographies: "Schmidt, Ralf, and Hans-Ulrich Schimincke. 2002. From Seamount to Oceanic Island, Porto Santo, Central East-Atlantic. Journal of Earth Science 91:594-614."

Source.Common.Name: Baksan
Geology: "Baksan obsidian is black with red mottling, and is typically found in secondary deposits in the Baksan River Basin (Doronicheva and Shackley 2014)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Baksan River, Mount Elbrus, Zayukovo, and Baksan Gorge (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Basaltic Plateau-1
Geology: "The basaltic plateau obsidian is of high quality and is known to have been transported for more than 300km. The lower parts of lava flows here usually have the largest deposits of obsidian, although there are large outcrops in the northern portion of the plateau, approximately halfway between the Sea of Japan and Lake Khanka (Dumond and Bland 2006)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Shoktovo Plateau (Jia et al. 2010)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. IAOS World Obsidian Source Catalog, Northwest Research and the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR."

Source.Common.Name: Basaltic Plateau-2
Geology: "The basaltic plateau obsidian is of high quality and is known to have been transported for more than 300km. The lower parts of lava flows here usually have the largest deposits of obsidian, althouth there are large outcrops in the northern portion of the plateau, approximately halfway between the Sea of Japan and Lake Khanka (Dumond and Bland 2006)."

Source.Common.Name: Basaltic Plateau-3
Geology: "The basaltic plateau obsidian is of high quality and is known to have been transported for more than 300km. Source.Common.Name: Belogolovaya
Geology: "The Belogolovaya obsidian source is found 'near the headwaters of the Belogolovaya Vtoraya River, on the northern part of Tynua Ridge near the summits of Bystraya and Tynua.' The glass ranges in color from black, grey, dark red, and may have a blue-grey tint (Kuzmin et al. 2008)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Kamchatka 7 (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Gladkaya River Group General
Geology: "There are three unique subsources for Gladkaya obsidian (Kuzmin et al. 2002). The use of the Gladkaya glass was rarely used in the Upper Paleolithic, but use became common in the Neolithic (Kuzmin 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Nosichan
Geology: "Near the center of the Central Range on the Kamchatcka Peninsula there are several obsidian deposits surrounding the Ichinsky Volcano. These deposits make up the largest obsidian source on the Peninsula. There are several geochemically distinct sources here: Ichinsky, Nosichan, Paypalpan, and the Belogolovaya (Dumond and Bland 2006). Nosichan obsidian is found as a single deposit near its namesake, with a few nearby taluses (Grebennikov et al. 2010)."

Geology: "Obsidian from the Obluchie Plateau is found either as a 'hardened crust of pillow lavas (or) as numerous fragments in a hyaloclastic matrix redeposited from pillow lavas' and are grey-black in color (Glasscock et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Xunhe Plateau
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Lake Osinovoe, Osinovoe, Osinovoe Rechka, Ozero, Osinovoe, and Osinoozerskaia (IAOS World Source Catalog, Glasscock et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Rainbow Mines
Geology: "Rainbow Mines produces 'Angular cobbles and small boulders of black obsidian (with a pink translucence) that has a red/orange cortex. A mine has extensively disturbed the area' (Moore 2009)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Lassen Creek and Rainbow Mine (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Samarga
Geology: "It is unknown when the primary deposit of the Samarga obsidian source is, but nodules along its river namesake suggest somewhere in the northern Primorye (Glassock et al. 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Basaltic Plateau Group General
Geology: "The basaltic plateau obsidian is of high quality and is known to have been transported for more than 300km. The lower parts of lava flows here usually have the largest deposits of obsidian, althouth there are large outcrops in the northern portion of the plateau, approximately halfway between the Sea of Japan and Lake Khanka (Dumond and Bland 2006)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Shoktovo Plateau (Jia et al. 2010)."

Source.Common.Name: Gladkaya River 1
Geology: "There are three unique subsources for Gladkaya obsidian (Kuzmin et al. 2002). The use of the Gladkaya glass was rarely used in the Upper Paleolithic, but use became common in the Neolithic (Kuzmin 2011)."

Source.Common.Name: Chania Dam
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Bibliographies: "Frahm, Ellery, Steven T. GOldstein, and Christian A. Tryon. 2017. Late Holocene Forager-Fisher and Pastoralist Interactions Along the Lake Victoria Shores, Kenya: Perspectives from Portable XRF of Obsidian Artifacts. Journal of Archaeological Science Reports 11:717-742."

Source.Common.Name: Ambohimirahavavy
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "There is a single obsidian dome in the center of the Ambohimirahavavy Caldera (Estrade et al. 2013), and there is no evidence of archaeological exploitation."
Bibliographies: "Estrade, Guillaume, Stefano Salvi, Didier Beziat, Soatsitohaina Rakotovao, and Raymond Rakotondrazafy. 2014. REE and HFSE Mineralization in Peralkaline Granites of the Ambohimirahavavy Alkaline Complex, Ampasindava Peninsula, Madagascar. Journal of African Earth Sciences 94:141-155."

Source.Common.Name: Lake Kraseno 3
Geology: "Obsidian has been identified at Lake Krasnoe, in the Chukotka Province of Russian Far East. Obsidian is found on the eastern bank in abundance, with scattered nodules on the west coastline. There are two variants of obsidian coloration: black, red-brown mottled or banded black glass, and a less common dull 'frosted' type. Some samples contain small (0.2mm) phenocrysts - but overall this source is excellent tool-quality (Grebennikov et al. 2016)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests alternate names for this source include Kankaren Mountain and Krasnoy Lake (IAOS World Source Catalog)."
Bibliographies: "IAOS. n. d. International Association for Obsidian Studies: World Obsidian Source Catalog. The Lake Kraseno Obsidian Source in Chukotka (Northeastern SIberia): Geological and Geochemical Frameworks for Provenance Studies in Berengia. Archaeological and Anthropological Sciences."

Source.Common.Name: Unknown Group-A
Geology: "Several artifacts from the Kuril Islands have been sourced to an unknown obsidian deposit. Two artifacts from Iturup Island have been designated 'Group A' (Phillips and Speakman 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: Unknown Group-B
Geology: "Several artifacts from the Kuril Islands have been sourced to an unknown obsidian deposit. An artifact from Kunashir Island has been designated 'Group B' (Phillips and Speakman 2009)."

Source.Common.Name: Mono Glass Mountain 3
Geology: "Mono Glass Mountain obsidian deposits can be found at the crest of Glass Mountain, at an elevation of 3390 m asl, northeast of Long Valley, California. To the west lies the Glass Mountain Ridge, a steep-sided formation at the northern edge of the caldera. Due to a past eruption, secondary sources of obsidian can be found two to three miles out to the east and northeast of the ridge, while the alluvial outwash is composed of many cobbles of low-quality obsidian (Giambastiani 2004)."
Ethnominerology: "Mono Glass mountain obsidians come in a variety of forms, ranging from red, brown, mahogany, and black - with the occasional porphyritic nodules. Obsidian from the peak is described as a translucent black with black bands, as well as opaque blacks with white inclusions, with occasional lacy patterns, phenocrysts, and some mahogany varieties (Giambastiani 2004)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Glass Mountain (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Kuredka Formation
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian is found in a 50-100cm thick band within the Kuredka Formation of Southern Somalia, near the city of Luuq just above the Jurassic-Cretaceous unconformity (Kassim et al. 2002)."
Bibliographies: "Ali Kassim M., L. Carmignami, P. Conti, and P. L. Fantozzi. 2002. Geology of the Mesozoic-Tertiary Sedimentary Basins in Southwetern Somalia. Journal of Africen Earth Sciences 34:3-20."

Source.Common.Name: Jebel Marra
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Black obsidian is present at Jebel Mara in tuff layers, as well as within the crater walls intermixed with ash and lapilli (Vail 1972)."
Bibliographies: "Global Volcanism Program, 2013. 2013. Volcanoes of the World v. 4.6.2, http://dx.doi.org/10.5479/si.GVP.VOTW4-2013, Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC. ; Vail, J. R. 1972. Jebel Marra, a Dormant Volcano in Darfur Province, Western Sudan. Bulletin Volcanologique 36(1):251-265."

Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian from Mount Kilimanjaro is found in layers underneath lava flows on the northern and southern flanks of the Kibo caldera, known as the Lent Group (Nonnotte et al. 2008)."

Source.Common.Name: Rungwe
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian at Rungwe is found as small nodules in the pumice deposits in the surrounding area. Evidence of expoitation by humans is abundant (Fontjin et al. 2012)."
Bibliographies: "Fontijn, Karen, David Williamson, Evelyne Mbede, and Gerald G. J. Ernst. 2012. The Rungwe Volcanic Province, Tanzania - A Volcanic Review. Journal of African Earth Sciences 63:12-31."

Source.Common.Name: Mount Gurui (Hanang)
Normative.Occurrence: Extensional Zone in Cratonic Continental Interior
Geology: "Obsidian can be reportedly found in the mountains bordering the northern valley of Mount Gurui (now called Mount Hanang), as well as some outcrops on the valley floor (Neumann 1902)."
Bibliographies: "Neumann, Oscar. 1902. From the Somali Coast Through Southern Ethiopia to the Sudan. The Geographic Journal 4(xx):373-387. "

Source.Common.Name: San Lorenzo
Geology: "San Lorenzo obsidian can be found on the Tajumulco Volcano, representing a chemically distinct source from Palo Grodo obsidian (Cobean et al. 1991). Although it was heavily exploited, this material is actually an ignimbrite and not obsidian (Doering 2002)."
Ethnominerology: "Archaeological use spans Formative sites in the immediate area south to the Oaxacan Isthmus occupations, Paleoindian sites in the highlands, and Archaic Pacific Coast sites (Cobean et al. 1991)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source includes Tajumulco-2 (IAOS World Source Catalog)."

Source.Common.Name: Dasht-i-Nawyr
Geology: "The Dasht-i-Nawur obsidian source of Afghanastan is found in the central basin, just northeast of the Zardqadah Volcano. The glass contains 'Phenocrysts of quartz, plagioclase, biotite, and kaersutite' and ranges in color from transparent to yellow-brown (Boulanger et al. 2012)."

Source.Common.Name: Gonag Giran
Geology: "Gonag Giran is found on the southern face of Bozgoush Mountain. The obsidian is typically found as nodules, although a thin layered deposit is present, and are a dark black (Niknami et al. 2010)."
Other.Names: "Literature suggests an alternate name for this source is Bozgoush Mountain (Niknami et al. 2010)."
